My personal opinion on this is...
Definying consciousness as something separate from our brains is like trying to define fire as a state of matter.

You can smell the fire, see it, if you get close enough it burns you, you can hear the fire as well if it's burning wood for example... It stimulates a lot of our sense at once, something we would expect from a physical thing, but fire is in fact... Not matter, is just a chemical reaction taking place called "combustion".

It's a similar situation to consciousness. All living beings that can experience the universe also experiences consciousness.

Consciousness is simply the information your brain in interpreting from the outside world, humans just made it complicated but we are not special at all. And by that definition, it is not something can transferred, it's not "something else", some kind of special property of the brain, it's simply what we are gathering from our senses. If your brain can't or has no information to interpret, you have no consciousness.

We can't really give a definition door consciousness when we are the ones describing concepts that we perceive in words created by us from nothing but our own evolutionary behavior, if you think enough that's just how it is, there is no deep meaning behind it's existence, it just exist

This provides a plausible explanation of how a basic consciousness can develop into something more sophisticated. It does not explain how it came about in the first place, nor even why it is necessary for sophisticated life. Saying it would be handy to move in the direction of food is not an explanation. Artificial neural networks are capable of even the more sophisticated emergent behaviour described here (only lacking the bodies to physically perform the actions), yet we generally assume that they are not conscious.

If it were not for the fact that every individual knows instinctively that they themselves are conscious, Occam's Razor would lead us to reject the existence of consciousness as both unfalsifiable and unnecessary to explain our observations. It remains a very mysterious thing. Maybe one day we will explain it, but it's hard to see how one could do so even with perfect technology.

Human consciousness is substrate independent, which means that consciousness occurs when complex physiological processes happen in specific complex patterns. Consciousness needs the substrate to exist but what the substrate is made of is not important. Only the computational patterns are important for the phenomenon of consciousness.

You're describing the consciousness in terms of matter.  It's not yet proven that that's the case. So the whole premise hangs on a shaky ground.

"Out Consciousness is likely to have evolved from less complex forms, as a product of evolution by natural selection."

What you essentially just said is that robots are conscious beings. If you make a perfectly working machine, it will have consciousness - because consciousness is directly created by the evolution of material matter.

That, sir, is one of the biggest jokes I've heard. Consciousness is one of the biggest evidences AGAINST evolution - creating a perfectly material object will not create consciousness. It is clearly something completely unrelated to the material realm. Near Death Experiences confirm this - clinically dead individuals being recorded as seeing objects and hearing conversations that were impossible.

Furthermore: evolution of natural selection would only work in a materialistic standpoint. It could - in this hypothesis - create a perfect machine that functions to keep itself working (not that I subscribe to this view), but it has zero impact on an innate understanding of awareness.

There is no purpose for consciousness from a purely rational perspective. It only exists in a concept of personal preference - requiring that it actually existed from the beginning, and is not a product of evolution.

The whole premise of your argument hinges on this: "If I fix whatever is wrong with this dead body, it WILL come back to life under every circumstance." And consciousness cannot evolve itself. There is no purpose for consciousness, so it does not at all work with the evolutionary model. This means that there has to be an ORIGIN with personal preference - an origin of much superior consciousness to create ours. Which debunks this whole model you have presented.

You can be "Of Consciousness" and not be "Conscious". Consciousness is given very distinct traits within the overall scheme of the Known Universe. The Logical Mind will for the most part seek to deny this, for to do so would be to acknowledge the false sense of superiority it has fought so hard to maintain. Consciousness is active in manifesting its physical design by the purest of will alone, whereas Intelligence must do so through the manipulation of matter. When evolving, both are completely capable of performing these tasks in their way. Consciousness can evolve with much more expediency and without the hindrance of forming its needs but simply manifest its growth. True consciousness is undiscovered by most of the world, they are thus far content to use titles such as Self-Consciousness or Awareness. The field that seems to be most intrigued about it at this time is Quantum Physics, for they have branched off onto a field of discovery that has given them systematic puzzles to ponder. Which may later allot for insights that the rest of the logical world would consider or even accept. They have already found what many spiritual beings have said for thousands of years: consciousness creates matter. This realization is tough to accept in the physical world, nothing so far in life is considered to be so simple. Surely, if a Greater Being created something from nothing out of thin air, Minds would block it from accepting this. I think I have it. We talk about consciousness like you have it or you don't, and I know humans are very complex. But what if it is a gradient? Or then what is the lowest benchmark. The idea of consciousness led to that, what is the simplest idea. Everything branches off something else. The simplest idea is that of "no more", On/off, or alive/ dead. Every thing past that is just more consciousness. I think the first organism that had sensors or whatever and had a brain capable of knowing that they were dying was conscious. Think about it. Life or death, on or off. Food or starve. Learn or die. If you don't procreate the species dies. And teaching offspring helps keep them alive/on. Memory, the extra stuff, is good for both teaching and learning things. Our human consciousness is a complex network on top of old networks with the main function to prevent the off/dying. I think eventually people will start talking about a world consciousness when we are all connected via internet. And just like a baby becomes an adolescent who becomes an adult, the world collectively will mature and think responsibly. I don’t think being aware of one’s surroundings or inner state (e.g. hunger) and can direct oneself accordingly necessarily means one is conscious. We don’t think of person-sensing CCTV camera as being conscious, or a sophisticated AI-directed drone or self-driving car. So who is to say that we are conscious really? How much are we very elaborate automatons with the illusion of consciousness? Do we really have free choice, or are (unconscious) slaves to our biology? For instance, we become aware of our hunger “consciously”, but we are utterly unaware of the internal biological conditions that developed into the sensation of hunger, and whether they are even real (or induced by advertising, say)?

I Have Observed That conditional Existence Is a limit that Inherently and Necessarily Frustrates The Great (As Well As The Ultimate) Motives Of conditionally Manifested beings. Therefore, every individual Must—Through Struggle, and Through The Grace Of Sudden (or, Otherwise, Growing) Insight, or Through The Grace Of Sudden (or, Otherwise, Growing) Faith (or Tacit Certainty)—Learn and Accept A Life-Lesson That Makes ordinary (or worldly) heroes Great and Grants Wisdom To those who Seek The Ultimate.

That Life-Lesson Is This: The Great “Creative” (or Even conventionally idealistic) Goals May Never Be Attained (and They Will Not Be Attained Without A Degree Of heroic Effort, or The Commitment To Struggle and self-Sacrifice)—but The Ultimate Goal (Which Is Happiness Itself) Can Never Be Attained (or Attached To the Apparently Separate self) By Any Means Whatsoever!

The Import Of That Reality Lesson Is This: If You Are Devoted To Great Purposeful Seeking In the conditional worlds, You Will Inevitably Fail If You Avoid Great Struggle and self-Sacrifice, and You May Not Succeed Even If Struggle and self-Sacrifice Are Fully Engaged By You. More Than This, If Your Goal Is The Ultimate (or Happiness Itself, Full and Perfect), You Will Necessarily and Inevitably Fail—Because Happiness Is Not Objectified (or Made Present As a conditional object In the conditional worlds).

Happiness Is An Inherent (or Unconditional and Perfectly Subjective—Rather Than conditional and Objective, or Objectified) Characteristic Of Existence, Reality, or Being (Itself). Therefore, Happiness Cannot Be Found (or Attained) By conditional Seeking.

Even If The Great Searches and The Great Goals Are (Basically) Oriented Toward The Elimination Of the conditions that Apparently Cause Un-Happiness—When Those Great Searches Are Fully Engaged (and Even When Those Great Goals Are Actually Attained), Happiness Itself (Full, True, and Not Threatened) Is Not Attained. Therefore, All The “Glorious” Adventures Of idealistic worldly heroes and All The “Romantic” Attainments Of “Creative” cultural geniuses End In Temporary Elation, Followed (Inevitably) By Disillusionment—and Then (At Best), Unless There Is No “Recovery” From Inevitable Disillusionment, There May Be A Reawakening Of The Stressful Motive To Seek and Attain Once More. (And Such Seeking and “Attaining” Will Tend To Continue—Until Disillusionment Itself Becomes Acceptance Of The Great Life-Lesson That Undermines All Seeking.)

Conventionally heroic and “Creative” personalities Tend To Grasp Only A Portion Of The Great Lesson Of conditional Existence. They Realize a genius For Struggle and self-Sacrifice, but (Unless—By Grace, and By self-Transcendence, Even By Advancing To The Ultimate Stages Of Life—they Realize The Truth Itself) they Never Realize Happiness Itself.

Happiness (Like Consciousness and Existence) Is Inherent (or Perfectly Subjective). Happiness Is Not Objectified (or Made an object), and It (Therefore) Cannot Be Attained By The Effort Of Seeking. Happiness (or Inherent Love-Bliss) Cannot Be Achieved objectively (or Accomplished conditionally). You Cannot Become Happy (Any More Than You Can Become Being, or Achieve Existence, or Become Consciousness, or Be Other Than Consciousness). You Can Only Be Happy (or Realize Love-Bliss Immediately, and Inherently, or Always Already, and Perfectly Subjectively). And, Likewise (or As A Corollary To This), You Cannot Become Un-Happy—Unless, In Reaction To any particular conditional circumstance or event, You Refuse To Persist In Being Happy (and, Thus, Refuse To Persist As Always Already Existing, and Most Prior, Happiness Itself).

. . . Consciousness and Happiness Are Identical and Self-Existing.

Clearly, Consciousness Is Not An Object. If It Were, What Would It Be An Object To?

Consciousness Is Inherently and Perfectly Subjective. It Is That To Which (and In Which) Great Objects and lesser objects arise and pass away. To Seek Consciousness As If It Were An Object Is Absurd—A Benighted (or Un-Happy) Quest, Founded On A Fundamental Misunderstanding Of Reality. Just So With Happiness!

Happiness Is Not An Object. If It Were, What Native (or Inherent) Quality Would It Modify or limit?

Happiness Is Inherently and Perfectly Subjective. And Happiness Is Inherent To The Inherently Perfect Subject (or Consciousness Itself). Therefore, Happiness Is That Native (or Original) Quality (or Inherent Force Of Being) That Is Apparently Modified, Apparently Revealed, or Apparently Decreased By The Apparent Association Between Consciousness and Both Great Objects and lesser objects.

To Seek Happiness As If It Were An Object (or To Identify It With any conditionally Manifested objects or others, or Even To Allow It To Depend Upon any conditionally Manifested objects or others) Is Absurd—An Always Already Benighted and Un-Happy Quest, Founded On A Fundamental Misunderstanding Of Happiness (or Reality) Itself.

To Seek Happiness (Rather Than To Realize It Inherently) Is To Be Possessed By the self-Contraction and To Be Motivated By it. Because Of the self-Contraction, What Is Inherent Ceases To Be Obvious—and (As A Result) the ego-“I” Seeks Among objects and others (and Even In the body-mind itself) For What Can Only Be Found (or Realized) Inherently, In Place, In The Well Of Transcendental, Inherently Spiritual (or Love-Blissful) and Self-Evidently Divine Being. Indeed, the ego-“I” Is Always Stressfully At Effort, In The Absurd Quest For Happiness and Consciousness.

Therefore, Listen To Me and Hear Me. Thoroughly Observe the self-Contraction. Understand Your Seeking and Your Separate and Separative self, Most Fundamentally. Grow (By Means Of My Avatarically Self-Transmitted Divine Grace, and Through Counter-egoic Heart-Response To My Avatarically Self-Transmitted Divine Grace) To Realize and Abide In No-Contraction (or The By-Me-Avatarically-Self-Revealed Native Love-Bliss-Happiness Of Conscious Being). In This Manner, Relax All Seeking For Happiness. All conditional objects (Including Your Own body-mind) Are themselves Contraction-Only. All Great Objects and all lesser objects Are Merely (and Only) Apparent Modifications Of The Inherent Love-Bliss-Radiance Of My Avatarically Self-Revealed (Transcendental, Inherently Spiritual, and Self-Evidently Divine) Being.

I was always slightly bothered when people refer to "consciousness" as something that a thing either has or does not have. I don't think its as black-and-white as that, I think some creatures have more or less consciousness than others, and even go through phases of being more or less conscious throughout their lifespan (like sleeping, or being distracted, or making decisions)
AND more importantly, I think consciousness is not just a 1-dimensional scale. I think it can branch, and something can be more conscious in one area than something else. For a small example, dogs and cats are much more conscious than us of our world in terms of scents.

But, that's just my personal "definition" of the word... I just feel like it describes things a lot more usefully than I see most other people use it.

This video completely misses the point by conflating consciousness with intelligence. (Which is quite astounding, since it begins by warning aganst such conflation.) There is no plausible mechanism by which consciousness arises from unconscious matter, and consciousness does not seem to add to evolutionary fitness in any way – as evidenced by a robot being equally apt at its task regardless of whether it has any complex conscious experience of it. The problem of consciousness is best solved by panpsychism, which this video grossly misrepresents by claiming that panpsychiststs believe a rock is a conscious entity. (Rather than a collection of tiny proto-consciousnesses that could form a more complex form of consciousness if ordered in particular ways, like in a brain.) Next time, don't ask a biologist to answer a metaphysical question; get a philosopher.

This is a significantly flawed video.   It completely misrepresents panpsychism, which does not propose that rocks are conscious, but rather proposes that all matter has some kind of proto-consciousness (with the 'proto' prefix being operative here - it is not being suggested that all matter is conscious) that gives rise to consciousness as an emergent phenomenon in certain material configurations like the brain.   Most egregious, however, is the failure to realise that if consciousness is a pure epiphenomenon, which it must be in a purely materialistic world view such as that implicit in your presentation, then it has no action on matter whatsoever.  There is therefore no advantage to be gained from its existence.  It  just goes along for the ride without any purpose or having any influence.  The same atomic, and therefore chemical, and therefore neurophysiological and ultimately behavioural phenomena would occur irrespective of whether or not there is a 'ghost in the machine' able to enjoy the pleasures of sex and fulfilling other appetites or feel the agony of being eaten alive by a predator.   If strict materialism is true, then from a physical and behavioural POV, a world with consciousness is indistinguishable from one without it.   As such, there would be no pressure for consciousness per-se to evolve.  The most one can say is that it emerged as a gratuitous by-product of the evolution of high brain functions.

Everything happening in this video, and in our behaviour, may well have evolved more or less exactly as very simply described in this video - without any creature being aware of itself at all.
This is easily demonstrated with recent developments in machine learning.
That is a process, computed by neural nets etc. I don’t think anyone is suggesting that an Android or robot dog is aware of itself the way you and I are.
What is being described in this scenario is the evolution of behaviour. 
Simple algorithms can result in very complex behaviour - but behaviour isn’t self-awareness.
So, unless we are going to basically kid ourselves and say that behaviour is synonymous with consciousness, we have to admit that we simply have no idea of the relationship of sentience to form.

I have the impression that everything alive (including basic organisms like plants and microorganisms) is conscious.

I don’t think there is a point where consciousness begins to exist along the gradient of complexity for its form in evolution. Although it helps identify the idea of thought, I don’t think awareness and it’s implication as a means of thought can be treated as a hand-in-hand necessity for the presence of experience, which I would classify as consciousness.

Even with the evolutionary approach in this video, you could argue that everything alive “wants” food. On every level, known forms of life obtain nutrients from something to stay alive, whether it be through photosynthesis, digestion or other weird methods. You can say that a venus flytrap isn’t conscious because it isn’t “thinking” to close it’s ‘mouth’ when a fly lands in it. A common argument would be that it is simply the reaction of the plant responding to stimulus, which in this case is just leaf hairs which react to touch by sending a subtle electrical signal to activate a chemical reaction responsible for the closing mechanism of the ‘mouth’. Even as the video said, a microorganism such as the Trichoplax adherens perform a function to consume. It moves aimlessly and doesn’t make decisions, but it still performs the function of consuming food to survive as a reaction to running into it. Through evolution, what life gains is additional steps (functions) in it’s reaction to help it’s survival - such as knowing when it’s hungry, or gaining the ability to smell food, or develop decision making by gaining a more complex brain, altering the experience of consciousness by adding more steps/layers. I don’t think consciousness “begins” somewhere in evolution. I think everything living is conscious, but on different levels of complexity.

Regarding the video’s claim to first-stage evolutionary organisms’ behaviour as mere “automatic responses”, you could say the same thing about humans and their actions. At a base level of every function we perform, everything could just as well be labelled as a “reaction to stimulus”. When something happens, a number of physiological reactions take place which are essentially electrical signals triggering chemical reactions and brain activity. Leading up to the current evolution of a human, our predecessors acquired a wider variety of chemicals and brain structures to expand on our capacity to respond in different ways to their environment, and we happen to be at a stage which, relative to the history of life forms on earth, have an enormous number of steps in ‘reaction’ to stimulus, but we’re still just as easily labelled as just ‘chemical reactions and electrical signals’.

The video is very intriguing and has some good suggestions, but I think it’s held back in it’s exploration of the interpretation of consciousness by it’s treatment of “awareness” as an implicit feature of consciousness. Without linear definition, I think the most non-specific way of ‘defining’ the extremely abstract existence of consciousness is the presence of experience, which we might not always be able to comprehend or imagine in different life forms because they don’t exist on the same level of complexity and functionality to us, such as a plant or germ, or even as some people might theorise, a “higher being” that is capable of functioning on an even more complex body and mind systems.

TLDR: I think anything that is living has the phenomenon of *experience*, and therefore is conscious.

I never understood the hard problem of science and this whole conundrum of consciousness. What am I missing? Why is it a big deal? We are just more intelligent to ask meta-questions about questions and turn ourselves inwards and so on, and that's what feels like consciousness to us. It's just about our ability to think in abstract and factors like time, memory, "identity," ego/self, cognitive focus, and so on are its functions.

We can't look at our eyes because to do so, we would need another set of eyes. But there's no center point of our experience. If there was one, then that would be confusing, because how come an object is looking at itself. That would be mysterious. But that's not how we really are. There's no single central point to our existence that is looking at itself.

"Philosophical Zombies" thought experiment also gives us nothing more. We can't have philosophical zombies that function exactly like us, but lack consciousness. They wouldn't be able to function exactly like us. End of discussion. It's bizarre to think that this world of philosophical zombies is EXACTLY similar to us in every way, except they don't have consciousness like we think we do.

So...what is consciousness? My answer is nothing. Imagine a special dog somewhere in the world, for a brief second, managed to turn its thoughts inwards. In other words, just had a thought about a thought and went "woah, that was weird." And that's just it. No big deal.

It just feels like a "problem" to us when we put it in unnecessarily confusing terms.

"Higher" consciousness , in that sense, is a function of the combination of material that makes up each individual. Higher levels of consciousness, due to being further evolved (note that evolved doesn't necessarily mean developed, just different) from basic levels, are unable to register the consciousness of simpler materials without specifically focusing on said material , but there is evidence that said consciousness exists . While this video gives some very compelling reasons for why consciousness evolved and details a logical procession of steps for milestones in the evolution of consciousness, it doesn’t actually explain the mechanism by which inanimate objects became living things capable of reproduction and self sustainability, or how an algae evolved to have sight… etc. That would require a molecular bioevolutionary chemistry lecture with references to experiments that haven’t been done yet. This observed hierarchy of consciousness in nature is merely one piece of evidence among a colossal amount that would be needed to actually prove that consciousness evolved. The title, “How unaware things became aware” assumes that consciousness did evolve and this is not a proven premise. Thus a better title for this video would be “a theory of how consciousness might have evolved, if it did.” I say this just for the sake of other people watching and to show that knowledge and science are not as straightforward as they are presented when shown for the greater audience. That being said, I thoroughly enjoyed the video, its brilliant animation, its creative display of consciousness, and the opportunity it gave me to practice critical thought about life and humanity.

Consciousness is an arbitrary descriptor of the degrees of intelligent awareness.

Awareness is the capacity to sense, acknowledge and respond to a state of affairs. Extent of awareness is primarily determined by 2 things: intentionality and rationality. Rationality and intelligence are synonymous and directly proportional. Intelligence is the capacity to collect information, infer rules/conclusions from it, relatively appraise the utility and truth of these conclusions and store them for later reference. On the other hand, intentionality is a sufficient condition of intelligence and describes the correlation between ration and action/response and the effects of ration on action/response. Intentionality can also be defined as the simplicity/difficulty and frequency that the rules inferred by ration are/can be applied to trigger responses and actions that help actualize ideal or desired states of affairs. [Just for interest sake: There are factors that harm intelligent awareness. For example, frequency and degree of whimsicality and involuntary responses are inversely proportional to intelligence and are negatively correlated to intentionality.]

[I'm sure there are far more components of intelligent awareness and more factors that influence it but I don't want to spend too much time drafting a YouTube comment. I'm also aware that I need to figure out the metrics and methods that I can use to measure these variables but I'm not there yet.]

To conclude, intelligent awareness is the extent of an entity's capacity to intentionally respond to stimuli and states of affairs to achieve an ideal state of affairs.

1. Things with no intelligent awareness are negatively conscious/unconscious. For example, corpses and pencils.
2. Entities that can sense and respond to some stimuli but barely or never rationalize their responses are quasi-conscious and superficially sentient. For example, fish and infants (I assume).
3. Entities that can sense and acknowledge internal and external states of affairs/stimuli and can (in many cases) intentionally respond to these stimuli to achieve something are positively conscious, self aware and neutrally sentient. For example, typical adult humans.
4. Entities who are entirely rational, can acknowledge and sense all active stimuli and states of affairs and cannot unintentionally respond are uber-conscious, ultra-aware and omnisentient. For example, a sage, a god, a demi-god, ethical vegans and Joe.

[P.S. After reading all this, you must know. This was a troll💀]

After watching this video I'm fully convinced that consciousness is not as complex as we think which is probably why we can't figure it out. It seems to me that consciousness is a combination of things such as chemical impluses and physical evolution. To explain further all of our senses boil back down to chemical reactions triggering electrical impulses that our brains process and interpret it. Our DNA along with our microbiom and our senses probably make up a good chunk if not all of our consciousness.

Think about it everything alive today came from single cells in the ocean at the creation of earth. And all those cells evolved in order to survive, however they were obviously very limited in their capabilities. And thus they evolved becoming more complex and capable to process more. Think of it like a computer the first computer ever compared to the number 1 computer today. The difference there is in a multiple of complex technological evolutions. So why does life evolve? Life evolves to continue surviving and whatever that specific thing is that causes us to evolve (DNA perhaps) tried and tried and tried many different combinations in order to survive. Which leads to all the various forms of life on the earth and all the various cells we have. It's been demonstrated in nature time and time again how different species and forms of life assist each other in a collective effort to survive. Plants and insects for example as well as large mammals and the birds that eat the parasites off them. Same with whales and smaller fish etc. All the way down the microbial life and even single cells (there's many cells in our bodies that work together to keep us alive and in every living thing). Think about how trees and fungus help each other out etc. Etc. And just as we have a vast range of life on this planet we also have a vast range of cognitive function. Which seems to be centered around the brain and it's complex design. For example a koala is the dumbest creature on the entire planet and it's because it had a smooth brain it lacks the wrinkles you think of when you picture our brains. And the most intelligent is the human brain which is evolved into what we have today. Same with eyes and nerves and sense of smell taste etc. All these different forms of evolution arose to forms of life that require it to survive. I truly believe (and I say believe because I have no way of proving it) that dreams are the origin of conciousness. I saw my cat dreaming one day and realized that what it was doing, basically, was rehearsing experiences that induce "relevant" stimuli (either pleasant or unpleasant ones) and seeking to either avoid or rehearsing ways to achieve them (she was fighting something in her dream). This has an obvious evolutionary advantage. Furthermore, the notion of something that exist beyond the realm of what we experience, this being dreams, would allow a species, over time, by trial and error,  to make the distinction of what constitutes "reality"(the time and place where we do things and they have an actual effect on us) and what does not (dreams).

There is no such thing as consciousness.

There is feedback from our senses, which creates a model of ourselves and a model of the universe around us, and we are capable of forming thoughts about that model.

This model of ourselves is 3d, thanks to our skin. Our skin provides a map of our body to our brain. This map is slowly built as we grow up. Babies have no concept of their hands, their feet, their presence. They slowly develop it by bumping their body around.

And since our body is part of the model of the universe the brain builds, it's only natural that the brain can talk about it. We call that 'consciousness'.

That’s consciousness or as I like to call it, “seeing.” It’s how a blind person is still able to see darkness, how a deaf person knows what silence sounds like, and how someone who can’t feel knows what nothing feels like.

Consciousness is nothing more than the processing of sensory information by a biological entity that can sense its boundaries. The more sensory information that the entity is capable of simultaneously processing, the higher level of consciousness it possesses. The cell possesses the lowest level of consciousness, humans have the highest level because of its brain capacity to process and store information. Artificial intelligence will have consciousness once it meets all requirements. The universe has no boundaries or capability to process information so there is not a conscious universe (sorry Deepak Chopra). Consciousness does not survive after the end of the entity because consciousness is an attribute of the entity.
The only way to deprive a biological entity of all its sensory processing capacity or consciousness is by killing it. Being in a comma or sensory deprivation room does not stop all sensory input. Our cells are in constant communication, and along with the nervous system give us our physical boundary. Don’t limit our consciousness to the rough thinking of our five senses; think chemical, electrical, pressure, and magnetic input processing. The brain creates memories (models/mental maps), assess risk/benefits, and calculate probabilities; the capacity to manipulate those processes is what puts humans above other species.

I don't think this video even came close to explaining how living things became aware. In terms of natural selection and evolution, it's not clear at all what consciousness adds to an organisms fitness function. Take pain for example. Pain helps an organism avoid situations that cause it harm. It creates a major disincentive for doing things like touching something that's hot, or getting poked by something sharp. But why does an organism need to actually feel the pain in a conscious sense? In theory, the pain could just be a chemical signal to trigger reflexes to avoid certain things. Very complex organisms that most scientists would agree are not conscious evolved and thrived without consciousness, and we now have AI-based software systems that most scientists would say are not conscious that have adapted to their virtual environments with incredible speed and precision. So the mystery of consciousness is far from solved. I'm not ruling out that consciousness is integral to evolution, but it's not clear to me at all why it is integral. It's utterly baffling.

I love this channel, but the hubris of thinking you can explain to people the nature or origin of consciousness in one of these videos is a little bit of a turn off.

This whole video is working off of an unstated assumption that consciousness is emergent from physical reality. But science STILL cannot answer the most fundamental question about consciousness which is whether consciousness is emergent from physical reality or if reality is emergent from consciousness. No matter how much we learn about the universe and it’s laws, we are still only experiencing it and measuring it through the subjective experience of our own consciousness.

The most honest null hypothesis is to prove that anything exists outside of consciousness, because as human beings we have never experienced anything otherwise. The universe only exists as we have experienced it.

It also starts this way over and over and over every single time a baby learns their first word. Every other word they learn allows them to become more and more intelligent until at last they become a conscious human.

My wife and I used to hang suet for the birds when we lived in Portland and the Scrubjays would eat the whole thing in one visit (they would break it up, toss it to the ground three stories below, then eat it down there). So, I would try to run them off. While doing so, I observed the most peculiar and amazing behavior.....they would move like a military unit and would make the same predictable, yet calculated, series of movements before they would eat.

They would make sure it was clear, from many angles and if they saw me in the window, there was a particular call and they would 'abort the mission'. They would position one individual in a location where there was some view....and the bird would give an al clear, at which point, the next Jay would move into position. They would always send the youngsters up to test the feeder first.

After awhile (I was a new stay at home dad with two infants....i had some free time), it was a game of chess between them and me. I often lost.

Thanks for this video! I have a few comments.

The thing is, we could programme intelligent, self-replicating robots to seek out raw materials, spatio-temporally model their environment and estimate the place of the sought materials in it, even model any competing robots and their intentions and behaviour. In other words, we could program them do all the things for which consciousness is here thought to have been developed. So we face one of several possibilities. Either such robots inevitably become conscious in the process of running such programs (if they are not already conscious for panpsychist reasons), or they don't become conscious, which then begs the question why we do when we run equivalent biological programs.

On a related note, I think we should take care to be precise about what we want when we ask we for an explanation of consciousness. We may want mechanical or functional explanations, i.e. ones answering the questions: "How can it arise within the laws of nature?" (technical) and "What does it do?"/"What is it for?" (functional/teleological), respectively. Or we may want something else entirely: a full qualitative description in terms of other observed phenomena. This would attempt to answer the questions "What is it?" and "What is it like?"

A little story to illustrate the difference:
You and I are deep in conversation about consciousness and absent-mindedly amble out into a crossroads. A car races towards us from the left, unable to brake in time. As I stand rooted to the spot facing the sudden, violent crescendo of time's winged chariot, you pull a stick from your pocket and point it at the approaching vehicle, whereupon it promptly disappears into thin air.

Still reeling, I ask you to explain what just happened.

You answer, "Well, I didn't want to die."

"Sure thing", I say. "So you whipped out your magic wand and vanished the car. Do you understand that my curiosity is not fully satisfied?"

"It was a perfectly sensible thing to do," you say.

"Absolutely. The question is how on Earth it was possible."

"Well, to get technical, modern physics is still a few fundamental concepts short of a solid theory of everything. One is thaumic force: a hugely powerful but usually dormant force, almost undetectable with our current set of instruments, which however responds directly to some people's conscious awareness and thus, with practice, permits them to physically manifest their conscious imagination. These people may be called witches and wizards. The wand is just style."

"OK, thanks. But what IS thaumic force. How does it relate to other forces? Is it one of them, part of them, or a combination of them? Or something else entirely?"

This channel is in painful need of a sequel to this video. As the video hints in the first minute, this video ends up exploring the less interesting definition of consciousness (and theory). The most interesting definition, relevant to the "hard problem of consciousness" is Thomas Nagel's version of consciousness: "what is it 'like' to experience something". The experience of qualia. Not object permanence, mental models, etc. This video is totally incomplete without touching on the "hard problem" in a satisfying way.

Characterization: Consciousness is the memory of having been conscious. (not recusive, being conscious and having consciousness are not identities).

Primary consciousness: The ability of an entity to change its dispositions to anticipated events based upon experiences prior to such events.

Secondary (human level) consciousness: The ability of an entity to change its dispositions to anticipated future events based upon experience derived anticipation of its own expectation of interaction with circumstances of those events.

These are both "low bars" and machines can and now frequently do do both of these things. What of it? There are many levels and significant dimensionality to both those definitions. A dog knows that it wants to play catch ... but knows it does does not want to in a thunderstorm. It has some awareness of itself in interaction with an anticipated circumstance. What it cannot do is significant forward planning ... it cannot abstract itself from circumstance and perhaps decide it wants a new ball for when better weather arrives. It is our Turing Completeness that segregates us, our abiitiy to think of our thoughts, and of ourselves as "things" free from current circumstance. But this is a cognitive or intellectual skill and not itself a requisite of consciousness.

Even if we look at a simple living being and say it must have needed to be conscious of its surrounding to survive, what on Earth does that even mean? How is that a proof of consciousness? Granted, I stopped watching the video because it has a simplistic definition. But if you like to think more deeply about it (like Descartes did) think of this...

Even if we build a humanoid robot (let's say it really really looks like a human, but it really doesn't have to) that has all of the detectors to react to its environment and produces all the outputs, just like a conscious biological human can do... does that mean it is conscious? I cannot even be sure that other humans are conscious (except, me, arguably). All we have is behavior. Make the behavior life-like, and it starts getting pretty confusing what our criterion for consciousness should be.

So forget rocks... and think like Turing did, and read his 1950 paper to see that it was more than about just fooling people with a "game of imitation" it was about replicating human behavior as best as possible, and arguing that this is as far as it gets, consciousness is out of reach for science, even today, because of Descartes's "problem of other minds" : we cannot access other minds (only our own). As far as others are concerned, all we have is guessing, and 400 years later, we are nowhere closer to solving Descartes's dilemma... it has only gotten MORE confusing because of robotics and AI, like Turing predicted). Whoever tells you that the origin of consciousness probably had to do with a supposed "need to be aware of our surrounding" is not grasping the Hard problem of consciousness (Chalmers, 1995).

The Hard problem is that even without consciousness, everything could (who knows, really...) work the same. Our nervous systems are made of what? Matter, atoms, following the SAME laws of physics that non-biological systems must follow (because they are made of the same atoms from the same universe, and periodic table). Remove the "awareness" and the game stays the same... the only difference will be that nothing matters. But it will sure LOOK like things matter (to some conscious "loner" who happens to pay us a visit). All we have to infer consciousness in others is behavior... and guessing. Feeling pain is not needed to get away from the fire, only nociception is needed (and nociception can be completely replicated using robotics... That fake fish reacts like a real fish to "painful" stimuli, but is it in pain...?).

All you need for survival (including us, no matter how complex we are) is behavior. Being conscious of it all seems disconcertingly superfluous the more you think about it. If you think I'm wrong, just think about it long enough (and make sure you read all of this properly), you will see.

I am a physicist and I will provide solid arguments that prove that consciousness cannot be generated by the brain (in my youtube channel you can find a video with more detailed explanations). Many argue that consciousness is an emergent property of the brain, but it is possible to show that such hypothesis is inconsistent with our scientific knowledges. In fact, it is possible to show that all the examples of emergent properties consists of concepts used to describe how an external object appear to our conscious mind, and not how it is in itself, which means how the object is independently from our observation. In other words, emergent properties are ideas conceived to describe or classify, according to arbitrary criteria and from an arbitrary point of view, certain processes or systems. In summary, emergent properties are intrinsically subjective, since they are conceptual models based on the arbitrary choice to focus on certain aspects of a system and neglet other aspects, such as microscopic structures and processes; emergent properties consist of ideas through which we describe how the external reality appears to our conscious mind: without a conscious mind, these ideas (= emergent properties) would not exist at all.


Here comes my first argument: arbitrariness, subjectivity, classifications and approximate descriptions, imply the existence of a conscious mind, which can arbitrarily choose a specific point of view and focus on certain aspects while neglecting others. It is obvious that consciousness cannot be considered an emergent property of the physical reality, because consciousenss is a preliminary necessary condition for the existence of any emergent property. We have then a logical contradiction. Nothing which presupposes the existence of consciousness can be used to try to explain the existence of consciousness.


Here comes my second argument: our scientific knowledge shows that brain processes consist of sequences of ordinary elementary physical processes; since consciousness is not a property of ordinary elementary physical processes, then a succession of such processes cannot have cosciousness as a property. In fact we can break down the process and analyze it step by step, and in every step consciousness would be absent, so there would never be any consciousness during the entire sequence of elementary processes. It must be also understood that considering a group of elementary processes together as a whole is an arbitrary choice. In fact, according to the laws of physics, any number of elementary processes is totally equivalent. We could consider a group of one hundred elementary processes or ten thousand elementary processes, or any other number; this choice is arbitrary and not reducible to the laws of physics. However, consciousness is a necessary preliminary condition for the existence of arbitrary choices; therefore consciousness cannot be a property of a sequence of elementary processes as a whole, because such sequence as a whole is only an arbitrary and abstract concept that cannot exist independently of a conscious mind.


Here comes my third argument: It should also be considered that brain processes consist of billions of sequences of elementary processes that take place in different points of the brain; if we attributed to these processes the property of consciousness, we would have to associate with the brain billions of different consciousnesses, that is billions of minds and personalities, each with its own self-awareness and will; this contradicts our direct experience, that is, our awareness of being a single person who is able to control the voluntary movements of his own body with his own will. If cerebral processes are analyzed taking into account the laws of physics, these processes do not identify any unity; this missing unit is the necessarily non-physical element (precisely because it is missing in the brain), the element that interprets the brain processes and generates a unitary conscious state, that is the human mind.


Here comes my forth argument: Consciousness is characterized by the fact that self-awareness is an immediate intuition that cannot be broken down or fragmented into simpler elements. This characteristic of consciousness of presenting itself as a unitary and non-decomposable state, not fragmented into billions of personalities, does not correspond to the quantum description of brain processes, which instead consist of billions of sequences of elementary incoherent quantum processes. When someone claims that consciousness is a property of the brain, they are implicitly considering the brain as a whole, an entity with its own specific properties, other than the properties of the components. From the physical point of view, the brain is not a whole, because its quantum state is not a coherent state, as in the case of entangled systems; the very fact of speaking of "brain" rather than many cells that have different quantum states, is an arbitrary choice. This is an important aspect, because, as I have said, consciousness is a necessary preliminary condition for the existence of arbitrariness. So, if a system can be considered decomposable and considering it as a whole is an arbitrary choice, then it is inconsistent to assume that such a system can have or generate consciousness, since consciousness is a necessary precondition for the existence of any arbitrary choice. In other words, to regard consciousness as a property ofthe brain, we must first define what the brain is, and to do so we must rely only on the laws of physics, without introducing arbitrary notions extraneous to them; if this cannot be done, then it means that every property we attribute to the brain is not reducible to the laws of physics, and therefore such property would be nonphysical. Since the interactions between the quantum particles that make up the brain are ordinary interactions, it is not actually possible to define the brain based solely on the laws of physics. The only way to define the brain is to arbitrarily establish that a certain number of particles belong to it and others do not belong to it, but such arbitrariness is not admissible. In fact, the brain is not physically separated from the other organs of the body, with which it interacts, nor is it physically isolated from the external environment, just as it is not isolated from other brains, since we can communicate with other people, and to do so we use physical means, for example acoustic waves or electromagnetic waves (light). This necessary arbitrariness in defining what the brain is, is sufficient to demonstrate that consciousness is not reducible to the laws of physics. Besides, since the brain is an arbitrary concept, and consciousness is the necessary preliminary condition for the existence of arbitrariness, consciousness cannot be a property of the brain.
Based on these considerations, we can exclude that consciousness is generated by brain processes or is an emergent property of the brain. Marco Biagini

What do you count as "being conscious"? In a pretty stagnant, unchanging landscape, that quality would probably be the capacity to perceive and identify a change to that situation in either time or presence, ie. something missing, new, both (a replacement), or the process of such situations.

Another level of that, called subconsciousness, could be assumed to be the effort to pay attention to something that can affect you, ie. have an interest or hate of something regardless of presence, time or distance (think of something you hate; that is you being subconscious of it).

The compounded effect of both consciousness and subconsciousness is called a reaction, a collective action from a learned experience saved to memory that might be instinctively brought up by changes to the situation.

That reaction, in response to what can become uncomfortable, is what you might call concern.

Why are we not just conscious less AI?

Plants and creatures have a well-known tendency to evolve into more complex beings as time goes by, so it is an easy assumption to make, that consciousness started off as a less advanced form of awareness. The fact that consciousness is a useful thing to have in order to survive explains the propagation of the development of consciousness.

However, there is (or surely must be, is what I'm thinking) something very specific that separated the first creature that was barely conscious, and its parent, and the fact that consciousness is useful doesn't explain how that change happened. Someone likely wants to say "it was a mutation", and while that's the assumed explanation for all other such abrupt changes in an organism's functions, "it was a mutation" doesn't even remotely satisfy my curiosity in the case of consciousness. It's just a lazy, evasive response.

Another extraordinary function of many animals is eyesight, and I can fathom (or at least accept) that at some point, a photosensitive nerve was spontaneously created as a result of a mutation, that developed into the eyes of today. But unlike photosensitive nerves, we don't understand the physical/chemical (???) mechanism behind consciousness, so we can hardly even speculate what that first, spontaneously created, consciousness-enabling "thing" was.

Another question that I still haven't heard a satisfying answer to is why animals are conscious, versus just having environmentally dependent behavior, much like what computerized machines, like cars, do (assuming computers are not conscious, but who knows?). A comparable phenomenon that is translatable to the context of how humans function, is sleepwalking. One may perform actions of questionable conscious intent, but nevertheless seeming curiously intentional, while very much less than conscious. The trichoplax adhaerens "does not need to be conscious of its environment", but its actions are clearly environmentally dependent, why can't our behavior be like that too?

My point is that an animal should not need to be conscious to exhibit environmentally dependent behavior. Memory, reasoning and the ability to make good decisions can exist without consciousness. We know, because computers can do those things. And when you criticize the capabilities of today's AIs (which admittedly can be quite jarring at times), think about how much time humans have had to develop their reasoning abilities. It's not a fair comparison, and still, many believe that it's just a matter of time before general AI supersedes our own.

Language confuses people. An instance of consciousness would be a "state of consciousness." A "state of consciousness" is synonymous with a "state of awareness." Since we do somewhat understand what a state of awareness is, and what it implies, this allows a much better basis for going forward.

Things that have a very basic state of awareness have little more than some record or memory of what has happened to them. At higher levels, there comes awareness of not only the environment, but an awareness of what might happen, or be made to happen. And, at higher levels still, of thoughts and the thinking process, as well as feelings and, potentially, even the thoughts and feelings of other complex entities existing in their own states of awareness.

Can a state of awareness exist in the absence of memory? Doubtful, as a state of awareness is without meaning unless memory is involved. Much as time without space or space without time, were such things even possible, would be meaningless, frozen and unchanging.

The disturbing part is that this could mean there is nothing that really separates man from other animals with a higher state of awareness relative to most, that it is, instead, merely a matter of degree.

The consciousness is the mechanism process in our brain that compares input of our senses to the construct that is an approximation of the conditions from the inputs we receive. This construct is what we call neurological connections in the brain. They act as both memory and logic circuits at the same time. The more accurate the inner brains representation of the inputs true conditions, the longer the comparison process continues. So our brains are an imitation of the universe as we can observe it.

Making duplicates to continue existing and making different conclusions about input conditions increases the survival rate of these comparison processes and therefore the most accurate of these comparison processes continue.

We are the results of successful understandings of the inputs we receive. We are like the searching and feeling tips of tentacles trying to figure out the rules of this reality by process of trial and error.

This inner comparison mechanism is not unique to organic life. In it's most basic form consciousness is nothing more than the processing of complex causation.

All we are is a combination of two things. DNA under the conditions it forms a physical body, and what we have leaned in the time we have been alive. It is only the isolation of the processes in the chain mesh of logical neuron connections in our brain that makes us individuals. If this limitation is removed, we are no longer individual and rejoins everything else that is not isolated.

Our evolutionary destination is to gain more senses, continuing to gain greater and more accurate representation of this universe into our minds until we are a complete copy of this reality.

Conclusion. We are the process of causation. It's the level of complexity in this chain mesh of causation that determines our level of consciousness.

Farther conclusion is that all of the known universe is a complex chain mesh of causation events and therefore the universe itself is the highest level of consciousness.

No, it's not. ------ What it is is the subject which experiences. It is not the content or the input of experiences. It's distinguishable from experiences by the fact that it is that which is experiencing... That's what makes it unique in a world of objects, thoughts, and emotions (all of which are objects, or "perceivables"). Consciousness is really the subject. It is that which perceives objects, thoughts, and emotions...but itself is not an object, thought, or emotion.

There are some poor logical arguments in this video. For instance, saying that rocks are not conscious because they don't have behavior. There are people who don't have behavior (people who are paralyzed, or "locked in") but we believe they are conscious. Furthermore, we can make a robot that responds to its environment (i.e. has "behavior") but most people would say it doesn't have consciousness. Therefore we can't prove whether something is conscious based on the presence or absence of behavior.

In fact, this video explains the evolution of behavior, but really does nothing to illuminate the mystery of consciousness. It may in fact be true that every rock, grape, tennis ball or atom has some form of consciousness that we just cannot perceive or understand.

Consciousness seems to be an emergent property of the activities of the brain, but if we had no consciousness ourselves, we would not be able to determine in a scientific investigation of a brain that it has consciousness. Because all we would see would be the activities of the cells in the brain - and from this we could not conclude that this brain has a consciousness. When we scan the brain, we do not see fear, thoughts, sensory perceptions and other conscious experiences, but only "the firing" of certain regions in the brain. And when we examine a motion sensor, we only see the physical basis on which it works. Perhaps he actually "sees" the movement, but we cannot see the "perception" of a motion sensor - just the physical equivalent on which the perception may be based.

The problem I have with this view is that consciousness as we know it isn't actually necessary for any of these things. I could, for example, create a computer program that was designed to read data from a few sensors, iterate through candidate models of reality, choose a best match, follow some basic decision logic, and move toward an arbitrary goal or even a potential energy source. Really, when you think about it, even a Roomba can do that. It "knows" that it needs to recharge, and it seeks information from its environment to help it pre-emptively find a way back to its charging station... but it's not conscious. Consciousness as I mean it when I say the word refers to an unmistakable, acute, axiomatic subjectivity - that is, not the awareness of self but the thing that is watching the awareness of self take place. No plausible mechanism for this has yet been proposed by science (or religion), so I feel like it's a bit premature to suggest it's a product of evolution, since all of evolution's goals can ultimately be accomplished without it anyway.

The correct theory of everything necessarily explains both physics and philosophy.  According to physics (which is the study of matter in motion determined by one standard model equation), the internal activity of a material object is a separable preprogrammed system.  Therefore, the interior of a material object does not have agency and authorship, which are the opposite of preprogrammed and determined activity according to philosophy.  But we define ourselves in philosophy as the author of our activity.  So, according to physics, the subjective self in philosophy is located in the world around all of us, not inside each brain or any other finite mechanical box.

consciousness does not equal awareness, its the subjective experience. I can have consciousness without being aware of it. Our awareness, specifically self-awareness. As you said, intelligence does not equal consciousness, despite the direct relationship to any given state of consciousness a person resides within-my point being, that awareness of an object is a specific arrangment of information within ones brain, and self-awareness is a result of a feedback loop of that information

specifically, we might define consciousness as "the subjective experience that appears to me to be directly correlated to the state of existence the energy that makes up my brain" (matter is energy vibrating slowly, no?). Its important to explain that it "appears to me as directly correlated" because that is the only way we can attempt to objectify with words what a subjective experience is. It may seem redundant, but only if you already understand these things well enough, because when you think about what it means to be subjective, there is no other real way we can go about describing the phenomana, simply for the lack of any real objectifaction of matter in the sense that we are used to

if we could say that its more than appearance, that means we would have objectified it, violating the notion of it being subjective. It has to be something only I personally can verify, otherwise again it couldnt have been subjective in the first place. Finally, the same principle hangs around the idea that its directly correlated, we cant verify causation of consciousness. So, subjective can only be defined as itself if you get where im coming from with all of this-hence why consciousness is only measurable in terms of itself, which is why we see we can not get any more specific than "consciousness". it is simply fundamental, and if you can recognize this, then you can start to see how the universe actually depends upon it to exist. Think about how it matter seems to be related to it, but we run into a real pickle when we realize that we can not seem to find any apparent reason our brains have a threshold. Perhaps one of the easiest ways to think about it is to examine the interconnnected nature of reality. All things are part of the universe, which is a closed system. So, as i push in one direction, its similar to moving through air as in that the universe around me is pushed back behind me as i replace itself the space it used to occupy. So, if all information is chained, why do i not have access to the information of all adjecant point, and all points adjecant to those? well, that would encompass the entire universe, which according to some quantumn theories like the multiverse, is going to be host of every possible thing. And to view everything possible is exactly like mixing all the colors together and painting everything with it-its utter blackness, the closest we can really envision to what nothingness is. This is exaclty what the point of singularity is said to be-all points of information condensed into a single point. Hence, if we ddint have consciousness, everything we still be the singularity, which when you think about it subjectively, gives a pretty nice explanation to how it managed to sponteously expand and form every point in the universe everywhere all at once. It activated itself just as consciousness activates itself, materializing from "thin air"(think, when you become aware of consciousness, its a new state of consciousness, and its like wow where did it come from? itself!) and if you dont get it, think about how (and be careful, its tricky because self awareness doesnt equal consciousness) consciousness always exists as a part of experience, always "touching itself" (we can feel things, yet we can not feel what we used to feel them with, yet consciousness somehow can be used to feel itself), and is as a result interacting with itself, propelling itself. Think about it like this-no matter how hard i try, i cant rationalize my consciousness away. I cant objectify it, because the moment i start thinking about it, it starts to expand into itself

I'm annoyed by the first comment on panpsychists, which states "some panpsychists believe even a rock has some inner life." What panpsychist makes this claim? None that I know of. I am a panpsychist and have developed the General Resonance Theory, which starts with an axiom suggesting that all things have some associated consciousness. But as with all other versions of panpsychism I've encountered this does NOT mean rocks as rocks have consciousness. Rather, the constituents of the rocks, at the atomic and molecular level, would have some highly rudimentary consciousness, but there is no suggestion that there is any consciousness at the level of the rock as a whole. So it's all about the organizational level at which a higher level consciousness inheres. General Resonance Theory suggests that multi-level nested resonances allow for the combination of the highly rudimentary consciousness in atoms and molecules up the complex biological chain, resulting in the complex consciousness that we and other mammals enjoy. Other animals also clearly have an organism-level consciousness. Plants probably at a very lower level of complexity also. Bacteria and protists, ditto. Rocks, not so much b/c they lack the organizational complexity to allow for these nested resonance chains.

A machine with primary consciousness will probably have to come first.

So no, no panpsychists believes that a rock has a selfhood and inner experience.

Evolution became a laughable myth in the 20th century, during which it was disproved by millions of discoveries. One such discovery is that polymerase is a product of it's own translation, which proves Special Creation. Another is the discovery that the cell's structural design is not generated by genetic information, but is instead passed on by reproduction from the reproductive cells of the parents (Cortical Inheritance/Cytotaxis) which traces back to the original created organism. Evolutionism is a philosophy which is contradicted by science. Over 100 yrs ago, Evolution Theory was plausible for naturalists because of their rejection of God. Biological science was rudimentary and archaic, and provided no information about the operations of the cell. Modern biology has very greatly changed what is known of genetics and biology. It has been discovered that life is based upon information which is digitally encoded and stored in a more compressed form than man's best computer compression schemes.

DNA is a material medium encoded with digital information which is compressed to a level greater than man's best information compression schemes, operates with linguistics by employing phonetics, symantics, punctuation,syntax, and grammar which is more complex than any spoken human language, operates algorithmically, operates semiotically (the application of meaning to a symbol and interpretation of meaning from a symbol), is prescriptive, functional, and possesses meaning. There is no potential for the material actions of chemistry to produce information, algorithms, and linguistics. They are non-physical fundamental entities that can only be produced by intelligence because they require forward thinking - consideration of and planning for the future. These facts are proof that all life was designed by a mind of supreme intelligence. Modern discoveries about biology have overwhelmingly demonstrated that evolution is impossible and creation is a scientific fact.

During an organism's development, the genetic information instructs the cell on how to turn on and off, like chemical switches, numerous sequences of information of the DNA in a supremely complex and yet to be understood orchestral arrangement of groupings and orders so as to build the structures of an organism. These patterns of genes being switched on and off is so complex that man will likely never be able to decipher it.

If you want to believe in evolution because you refuse to acknowledge the existence of our creator, nobody can stop you. But doing so is to be a denialists of the discoveries of modern science because the truth is uncomfortable, and to continue to believe things which the outdated concept of Charles Darwin over 150 yrs ago could not have predicted. Believing in evolution today is as antiquated as it was to believe that flies arose from meat, or that frogs arose from mud a century prior to Darwin.

Random genetic mutation experimentation has been conducted for over 80 years. Over one million studies have been concluded, and they have provided consistent results demonstrating that random mutations are destructive and have negative effects upon organisms, both biochemically and anatomically, and do not add anything useful to the physiology of any organism, not even incrementally. I dislike reductionist explanations. Yes, our senses likely evolved in order to succeed in what biologists call the "consummate goal" which is usually reproduction, this of course required survival.
So yes, it makes sense that senses were first developed to increase success in the consummate act of the being's life. That was millions of years ago for one thing and is not necessarily representative of our current reality unless we assume that evolution is only sex and food in which case it should be termed "consummate act heuristic genetic durability" or some shit. Evolution is more than that. But again reductionism. I believe evolution is bringing us towards a higher state not just loping along looking for pizza and oral. For some that's all there is but that's not representative of all people.
In any project there are stages: eg fix spark plugs, paint red, clean and buff, fill with gasoline, go downtown and work with a financial analyst to increase your retirement savings.
The final step is qualitatively and quantitatively different. If evolution (as displayed) increases adaptability relative to the environment to ensure the consummate act / survival, why do we assume it does not continue with higher adaptations which are now neccesary. And so on across time. In a million years will evolution still be figuring out how many feet to have or how to interact with the changed world the person now exists in?
TLDR; Reductionism makes science easy but makes it lose 90% of its assessment/predictive value. Our minds are evolving now in reaction to the world we are making so in a real way we are unknowingly designing our future selves.

This is a fascinating discussion of the evolution of the traditional senses and abilities of the brain, and it's informed by generations of scientific discussion on what we can constitute as representative of consciousness- but for a video on consciousness there is precious little time spent on this. This could be the beginning of a great series- I'd love to see more philosophy preamble contextualizing the claims being made each time. Here, for instance, it feels like there should be some commentary on the obvious counter thought experiment: if we can build a computer with identical capabilities as a human, does that mean we have created a conscious being? Is consciousness and awareness inherent to clusters of matter, or a separate sense function that a complex nervous system can develop?

Tl;dr I love this channel and its consistent attention to detail and language, I would love to see more videos on consciousness that tackle other perspectives and questions!

Consciousness is typically attributed to animals whose behaviour (questionably) implies thought-processes that (also questionably) seem too complex to be automatic.


In the example at 7:10, the Western Scrub Jay is suggested to demonstrate Theory of Mind when it reacts to other Jays spotting its food cache.

This is implied to mean the Jay is conscious, since Theory of Mind is a thought process that simpler animals (presumably) don't have an analogue for.


However, this is just another example of the difficulty we have with separating intelligence from consciousness. Even if complex thought processes like Theory of Mind WERE necessary for the Jay to behave intelligently (by re-hiding its food when detected), this tells us nothing about whether these thoughts exist at a phenomenological level (are experienced) or whether they are only present on a physical level insofar as a truly-conscious entity (such as I, and I assume also, anyone sufficiently similar to me) observes them happening "from the outside", either by inference from their visible actions or by measurement (perhaps with neuroimaging equipment) of what we suppose to be the "thoughts" in question (since its not clear what the nature of correlation is between brain-states such as action-potentials, etc and the conscious qualia we ultimately experience), as represented physically within the brain of the bird.

There are 2 different perspectives to look at this other than the biological perspective.

First the physical or chemical perspective.
What gives an element its characteristics?
This question really bothered me when we learned about atoms in school. What element an atom is is purely dependent of its protons. Why is that so? How does adding a proton to an element make it a different element? When you think enough about it you will realize that the other things you learned about atoms, the mass for example, aren't much different. When you add neutrons to an atom, what exactly did you change? When you add electrons to an atom what did you change?

We tend to easily accept the mass and electrons because we learned how it affects the atoms before.
When the number of electrons of an atom changes and it becomes ionized, the way it interacts with other ions changes and that's basically it. When you change the mass of an atom the way it interacts with forces like gravity changes, nothing else. When you change the number of protons of an atom the way it interacts with other atoms, to form molecules, changes.

All characteristics atoms have are purely dependent on how they interact with other atoms and particles.
There might exist millions of other elemental particles that we will never find because they don't interact with anything we can perceive. When an object interacts with light we can see it with our eyes or with cameras. When an object is too small for that we need other ways to find them. One way is to find out if they interact with electrons that are shooted at them. This way we can get similar results to shooting the object with light.
This is how new particles are found, by the way they interact with other particles we already know. If there was an object that was simply existing and could not affect other objects when colliding with them we would never find out. When experiments are made and the results differ even though the two scientists did everything the same we know that there might have been some particle that we never saw before, but only because it affected the results.
We know about gravitational waves because we were able to measure how they affect objects we know.

And that is all there is to it. An object is purely defined by the way it interacts with other objects. What we call the appearance of an object is just the product of it interacting with light and the light interacting with our eyes.

The second perspective is very similar, you could look at it from an informatics perspective.
We had a school project in which we programmed a game in Java.
From working with an object oriented language for the first time I gained some amazing insights that made me understand the problem with elements and protons in the first place.
When you create an object it first does nothing. You can give it a position and attributes, that would be the equivalent of mass or electrical charge, but even giving the object these attributes still doesn't make it "exist" in a way that is meaningful for the program. It's the same for particles and consciousness. There may exist many forms that we've never discovered, because they don't interact with anything we can perceive. In the program I could give the objects pictures so they were at least visible. But not every object can be represented with a picture. If an object doesn't have any visual appearance on the screen and doesn't interact with objects that are visible then what is the object? Does it actually exist? For the computer the object does exist and takes up memory, but for the other objects that just don't interact with it does it even exist?
The conclusion is that the attributes don't even have any meaning and are just values that we assign to the object to be able to calculate how it should interact with other objects.
Without the object interacting with us or any other object to create a result we can measure there is no way for us to find out about all the hidden objects in the universes inaccessible memory.

In the Pleroma there is nothing and everything: it is not profitable to think about the Pleroma, for to do that would mean one’s dissolution.
I say these things to you in order to free you from the illusion that it is possible to think about the Pleroma. When you speak about the divisions of the Pleroma, we are speaking from the position of our own divisions, and we speak about our own differentiated state; but while we do this, we have in reality said nothing about the Pleroma. For this reason we must distinguish individual qualities.

Then we reach beyond the limits of our own being; we extend ourselves beyond the created world, and we fall into the undifferentiated state which is another quality of the Pleroma. For this reason the natural impulse of the created being is directed toward differentiation and toward the struggle against the ancient, pernicious state of sameness. The natural tendency is called Principium Individuationis (Principle of Individuation). This principle is indeed the essence of every created being. This video is a speculative rabbit hole. 1. You DON'T know that we "evolved," nor can science prove so, you simply BELIEVE we did. 2. Since you DON'T know what "consciousness" actually is, you CAN'T possibly know how it "manifested," or "came about."
While the majority of your videos are educational and fun, a lot of them are just ideological fancies and "trains of thought" masquerading as serious scientific inquiry, and some of them- like your "how evolution works" are just plain junk science.
IF you want to claim to be "scientific" you have to follow the scientific method; (1) hypothesis, (2) testing, (3) falsification...subjects such as "evolution" don't meet the strictures of the methodology (it's been stuck at step 1 since it was first proposed), and neither does this silliness.
IF you could PROVE evolution was a fact scientifically- which you CAN'T- this video might have some merit, as it is, it's just another venue for you to push your "evolutionary" hypothesis.
