I started thinking about consciousness as the result of trillions of cells individual needs. So our brains function to allow the greater organism to move and act in the best interest of our cellular conglomerate. Basically our consciousness is a way of organizing the cells of our body into a single goal.
So what we experience as consciousness is just an automatic response to an incredibly complex system of parasitic and cooperative cell colonies.
Just like a fungus can drive a grasshopper to drown itself, or an ant to its colony, or a mouse to sacrifice itself to a cat. Our cells drive a kind of consciousness. The only difference is our mode of being in the natural world.
Everything a human being does benefits a different cell type and structure of the human anatomy.
From the food we eat, to the exercise we enjoy, to our hobbies and career paths, we are just what our cells need.

This video completely misrepresents/misunderstands what the real problem is. Consciousness is the conscious perception of all of the sensory inputs of a living being.
Now the actual question is: How does nature construct this perception/projection of our senses? All this video does is describe the development of these senses, not how a consciousness is _constructed from them_. THAT is what is so strange and mysterious, not the physiological development of terran lifeforms, which is pretty straightforward as a basic concept.

Let me try to explain what I mean: Lets take the sense of vision as an example. Photorecoptors are being stimluated by light and in turn stimulate neurons in our brain responsible for their interpretation. Now in physical form these neurons are just a 3-dimensional network of information-nodes in our brain, right? But what we ACTUALLY SEE is basically like a screen with ca. 180/70 degrees horicontally/vertically containing all that visual information. Now here is the quesion: How is this virtual screen constructed from some discrete nerve cells in our brain that look NOTHING like it. Where is the screen? Its not actually there, its a projection. But HOW is it projected??

That for me is the question of consciousness. Same with all the other senses.

The fundamental problem with this video is to use external behavioral observations to attempt to define an inherently internal *experience*of consciousness.
There are plenty of behavioral phenomena displayed by things that we consider unconscious that might place those things in the category of sentient/conscious by mere external behavioral observation, but there’s no way for us to determine if they are in face having an experience of consciousness.
Plants, fungi, unicelular organisms, robots all display signs of conscious behavior that we,humans, also share, like memory, planning, movement, self-replication, etc. But somehow we assert that we are conscious, and they aren’t. If we dove deep, the line between us, our consciousness, and our cells (the physical matter) that makes us, gets very blurry.
The question then becomes, when does matter go from having no experience, to actually having one?
There’s no way for us to know what it is like to be something else...

I’m enjoying this content.  I would however like to point out, several of the examples are not examples of consciousness but intelligence.  The single cell example, for starters.  You say the cell spends less time where there isnt food by moving quickly,  but more food will equate slower motion.  That is actually an example of intelligence.  However hunger, or the need for fuel, is a very good example of conscious behavior.  To be conscious is only the awareness of self existence.  It doesn’t need to pertain to intelligence(or thought). It’s proposed consciousness is the bi product of any body with many moving systems that are autonomous.  For example, earth or mars or the entire galaxy for that matter, may be conscious.  Now if one of those bodies began rationalizing complex choices.  Based off information received from the many systems, that could argue intelligence.  There is a plausible hypothesis there as well, global warming/cooling could very well be from intelligence outside a brain.  Most likely it’s a cause and effect from trapped gasses being released via nature(humans, animals, volcanoes, methane pockets). "I regard consciousness as fundamental. I regard matter as derivative from consciousness. We cannot get behind consciousness. Everything that we talk about, everything that we regard as existing, postulates consciousness." - Max Planck, the father of quantum physics, Nobel Prize winner

"All matter originates and exists only by virtue of a force which brings the particles of an atom to vibration and holds this most minute solar system of the atom together... We must assume behind this force the existence of a conscious and intelligent Mind. This Mind is the matrix of all matter." - Max Planck, the father of quantum physics, Nobel Prize winner

"The stream of knowledge is heading towards a non-mechanical reality; the Universe begins to look more like a great thought than like a great machine. Mind no longer appears to be an accidental intruder into the realm of matter... we ought rather hail it as the creator and governor of the realm of matter." - James Jean, a notable English physicist

"I incline to the idealistic theory that consciousness is fundamental, and that the material universe is derivative from consciousness, not consciousness from the material universe... In general the universe seems to me to be nearer to a great thought than to a great machine. What many call the soul has 3 main characteristics .

1) Consciousness

The capacity to be aware of ones existence and the existence of other concepts which manifest to the consciousness as a feeling

2) Freewill

The capacity to encourage a concept or encourage the opposite of a concept or encourage both the concept and its opposite concept simultaneously ( which results in both of them cancelling out )

EG : do eat or do vomit or do eat and vomit simultaneously (cancelling each other resulting in the state of not eating or vomiting )

3) individuality

As an extension of freewill the sense of individuality is developed that the will of the “I” is my own for I am my self and my self possess my will !

The combination of these three properties of the sentient soul results in the perception : I am what I will and my will is my own therefore I am separate .

But what is the sentient mind to which these properties emanate from ? how can it have choice to become something ?

In order to have choice or freewill you need to be beyond the laws of the physical because self governance is only possible if the governance by external laws is absent atleast in some specific aspect .As we do have choice we experience freedom from shaping properties and as a consequence of that we experience shapeless as a further consequence of that we have the potential to shape our selves because unlike other constructs of the universe our form and behaviour is not completely limited and shackled by set laws so there is nothing preventing us from making our own decisions or in other words our own shape. Experiencing freedom from shaping properties means that we experience nothingness, and as the mind is individual we can assume that it is not itself nothing but it is an abstract individual experiencing infinity .would be better said that we are individual abstract entities experiencing shapelessness, nothingness,zero . Within this experience of zero is the experience of infinity as the zero is only the resultant of negative and positive infinity .


In order to know what to do , what to donot , what to encourage and the opposite of what is to be encouraged we require knowledge . Through conscious experience we gain knowledge and exercise freewill according to knowledge and the priorities ,aims we create using knowledge .

In order to enhance our freewill we create many mindsets , some of these directly strength freewill others allows us to better organise our knowledge and use it to conclude our stance towards certain concepts , and unlock new knowledge using old Knowledge , problem solving etc. As knowledge further enhances it freewill .

EG :critical and inquisitive thinking ,
linguistic organising ( assigning a unique relation ship between a concept and some other memory ,thought , sound , symbol in order to experience that concept as unique and separate .)

In all of this and the further priorities , mindsets ,philosophies we form ; It is forgotten that we created certain priorities for ourselves according to which we govern ourself and use freewill ,instead we start thinking that our behaviours are predetermined and therefore our freewill is an illusion .

To make a machine conscious you need to make it capable of telling you what it is perceiving in a given percept.

I think to understand consciousness, we have to follow reasoning without prejudices. Surprosingly, consciousness is acally a word. It has a relationship to the language cortex. We ask "are you conscious of X"? Example: are you conscious of your blood sodium level or heart beat? The answer is no. Your body knows it very well and controls tightly, but there is no pathway how to reroute that information into your language cortex. Consciousness is the set of percepts that can be queried inside the brain and rerouted to language cortex or other part of brain that is able to transmit information outside the body - by speech, gesture, facial expression etc. When you sleep you can talk about your dreama later but cannot talk about what was going in your head during deep sleep. Therefore you are conscious of dreams, but not of deep sleep. Your visual cortex perceives thousands of edges and corners every second but you are not conscious of them. You can reroute them into your language cortex on demand and become conscious of them. Example: "how many lines does my lower eyelid form?"

At 2:49 this video deems trichoplax adhaerens to be non conscious. But this video also acknowledges that consciousness is a series of microsteps forming a gradient of consciousness. Wouldn't this non random movement be one of those microsteps leading up to complex behaviors? It seems to me that this might be an example of simple consciousness and that assigning a line after this point might imply an additional, magical meaning for consciousness.


If we assume that complex systems are made up of simple systems, than would not this simple, repeating behavior constitute on of those simple systems of which to be selected from prior to evolving complex systems that may or may not have the option of rotating left as opposed to right?



People have a tendency to impose magical ideation onto consciousness, but if behavior is just the aggregate of our programming then even the simplest behaviors impact our survival and are thus shaped by selective pressures. The brain isn't just its atoms. Its also the spaces in between those atoms shaped by the forces indirectly acting on the brain due to entropy. And just like life itself, we are animate systems made up of inanimate parts. Taking this into context, even the evolutionary process itself is an empirically real response to objectively real external stimuli, and would constitute a slow moving consciousness. And that consciousness is just a biased perspective of any operation. The subjective perspective of an ongoing program or a chemical reaction.

There are many steps inbetween trichoplax adhaerens and humans, but I don't see an obvious clear break between my consciousness and their non consciousness. Perhaps because there isn't one.

This video is about cognitive functions, not consciousness. It completely misses the point.
The question is not why, for example, an inner representation of the world is useful, but why it is experienced. Consciousness doesn't cause anything, it just is. Every explanation that makes it useful for something is fundamentally wrongheaded. By it's nature consciousness must have developed accidentally as a byproduct of something else.

This video is suprisingly one-sided. Panpsychism argument is not about rocks having inner life, that is a big misconseption. The video still doesn`t explain  at what point consciousness emerges, where is the edge beyond which non-sentient things are. Gradient metaphor is nice but doesn`t work: what do we take as beginning of the gradient then? Emergent theory has a lot of downs, there is a reason why scientists are still looking for a better paradygm. Panpsychism just suggests that maybe there is some inner property of the matter that can lead to consciousness. There must be since animals and rocks are composed of the same matter.

My conjecture is that there will never be a satisfactory scientific theory of consciousness. There is a very good reason for this, which is that because consciousness is a subjective experience it cannot be detected objectively. In other words if some genius comes along and says they know the source of consciousness and they build a machine which they claim is conscious, it will never be possible to objectively prove if that machine is conscious or not. The only way to know if the machine is conscious is for the observer to become the machine and have the experiences of the machine which is of course impossible. It will never be possible to be certain that the machine is not just mimicking a conscious being due to elaborate programming etc.
In places you are confusing intelligence with consciousness. ARTIFICIAL intelligence (AI) can mimic intelligent behaviour without any need to invoke consciousness.

Much of this is completely irrelevant. Conscious is not needed for sense - response, engineers can build machines that do this, more sophisticated AI can mimic such behaviours as learning and memory. There is no reason to think the machines are conscious.

What is consciousness? And why does all emotion fear it?

Many speak of consciousness, but few ever describe what it means to be fully conscious. What it actually means to be in the state of consciousness.

In short consciousness IS NOW.

And by that I mean. When you are fully conscious, or fully aware, you then
have complete presence of mind.

You are then fully present.

And the present is of course NOW.

So, consciousness IS NOW.

Now, when you do correctly understand that consciousness is NOW, it is then far easier to understand why all emotion fears the evolution of consciousness as it does.

And more importantly, why emotion is working as hard as IT is in order to hinder the continued evolution of the state of consciousness on planet earth.

You see, all emotion is actually born of the past. All emotion is past.

Emotion is actually the residue of the past that continues to live on, both in us, and off us.

Hence exactly why, in this currently emotionally driven society, we are all taught from birth to habitually both talk, and think, about the past.

As by doing so, we are unknowingly helping to feed those very emotions that are actually living off us.

We have actually been conditioned to unknowingly create a feed back loop.

A feed back loop that was designed to help those very emotions that are continually draining us of our precious energy.

And when I do say US, I of course mean LIFE.

As I am in fact LIFE.

I am the LIFE in this body.

So, why does all emotion fear the evolution of consciousness on planet earth?

Well, as our speed of consciousness continually increases. As we become more NOW in other words.

So in turn, is there ever less room for the past. For emotion to actually express itself.

As of course in the present, in the moment NOW, there is no past.

Now, there is also another important fact that you must understand about NOW.

About consciousness.

And that fact is, that in the NOW, in the present, there is no motion whatsoever.

That in the NOW everything is in fact ‘absolutely still’

I mean, just look at NOW intelligently for one moment.

Now, now, now, now, now, now, now, now.

In the end, the perpetual moment NOW actually moves so fast, that in reality it does not in fact move at all.

Just as I said above, the moment NOW is in fact ‘absolutely still’

Now, as all emotion depends wholly upon the ability to express itself, to move in other words.

As the word e-motion so clearly proves.

Of course, something that relies as greatly as emotion does, on the continued ability to move. Is going to work rigorously to avoid any state that is actually devoid of all motion.

As in that state, the emotion can see its own eventually demise.

Emotion fears stillness.

As stillness (of mind) is GOD.

“Be still and know that I am God”

That unending state of calmness and tranquility, that is deliberately being destroyed by your many troublesome emotions. Along with the emotions of others.

Peace be to you.

I find that taking a more...spiritual view on the concept of consciousness at least gives me a relaxing peace of mind. Not in the sense of religious, but more like meditating on existential subjects and the nature of the universe and beyond. I'm going to make it clear now rather than later that all of this is MY OWN interpretation of these concepts and are not scientific in any way what so ever. Also I'm sorry if a lot of this doesn't make sense, but I'm not very good at putting my thoughts into words. In simplest terms I describe intelligence as an understanding of existence, and consciousness as an awareness of existence. When I say existence I refer to EVERYTHING that exists including the existence on that which does not exist. ("Oh cuz yeah that makes it REAL obvious to reader, and TOTALLY won't confuse them so much that they just give up reading this."my inner monologue as I'm typing this.)
I guess it's time for a bit of story telling of sorts to hopefully clear this up even slightly. When I was about 14-15 years old I was in an accident at a hospital that made me physically dead for about 30 minutes. During that 30 min I was in what I can only describe as the afterlife for what only felt like 3-5 seconds in a place that fit the description of what appears in the world of truth presented in the anime "Fullmetal Alchemist: Brotherhood" (minus the giant doors and creepy guy sitting in front of me) which is based on the Theory of Forms presented by the philosopher Plato. In short what I'm trying to get at with this story of mine is that this life changing experience played a major role in me coming to this conclusion as well as many other views I have on concepts such as morality, mortality, the meaning of life, and etc. So even if you couldn't follow anything I said I can't blame you, and I hope it was at least an interesting read.

I've had that thought about whether rocks could be conscious. Sure, it sounds stupid, but if you think about it all that's going on in my mind is electrical signals interacting with other electrical signals. Sure the signals can "think" and "act" as if it's self aware, but where does my conscious experience of it come into the picture? Surely my human body could function like a robot without my sentience experiencing everything that it's processing? Why am I "experiencing" it at all, and why don't I experience things outside of myself?

Can less sophisticated things experience things too? Can a rock feel on some level when it's been chipped, or does it actually need the complicated equipment to sense and process that? If sensory organs and a brain are necessary, then what about things like smart cars? Even if it's only physically possible for them to do what they're programmed to do, are they "experiencing" the world on some level like we do?

Consciousness is a virtual property of a virtual entity (the self) having a virtual existence in a virtual world (the brain's world model), all this running on a physical hardware (the brain). Being a virtual property of a virtual entity, consciousness does not exist in the real world. The brain is not "aware of itself". However the brain attributes this property to its self-representation in its world model.

I'm not convinced consciousness evolved simply from the need for food. After all, what about other factors such as reproduction, finding a mate? Of course I think that's all rather moot and irrelevant when it comes to consciousness, as is being able to sense your environment. And the proof is in the pudding. Consider a human brain in a vat. You'd be cut off from all your senses yet you'd still be conscious. You'd be alone in a dark void with your thoughts, but still conscious nonetheless. You would no longer have any need for food, as you now lack a stomach. It goes without saying that this level of consciousness is completely unnecessary for something as simple as gathering food. Indeed even a machine could emulate basic human survival strategies despite not having consciousness.

Hey! Just wanted to drop this by..
I believe you have made, perhaps, a mistake in the video: when you are talking about the worm with the funny face, you talk about him as if he has gained himself a consciousness, attributing to him adjectives such as 'hungry', which only apply to conscious beings, while you instead talked about the previous example in terms of chemical reactions leading to the fulfilliment of a lack of chemical resources (and not in terms of feelings-felt-by-the-consciousness).
Then, to the opposing answer - 'Well, but how? What's the underlying thing that made the worm conscious?' - you answered by saying that the worm had a nervous system. But what is it then about the nervous system that did give rise to that consciousness? In what way the appearence of the nervous system allowed consciousness to exist? That is what's missing in the puzzle. At a very basic level: what is it about certain physical properties that give rise to the consciousness?
I believe that, instead of them causing such consciousness to appear, they themselves are consciousness in itself. They appear to be such that they themselves are, instead consciousness. What do we know about them? This: once they appear, there is consciousness; once they aren't there anymore, there is no consciousness. (Or do we? Do we really know? Or are we just guessing?)
We then ask: why do they allow consciousness to exist? Yeah. And there lies the problem, right in front of us, that "something" that we can't possibly understand. How did we get to this point? By asking just one more 'why' than necessary. We had arrived: they are there, and there is consciousness. Well then.. why can't they be consciousness themselves? That one more "Why" is unnecessary! Or so i believe, at least.

Think about it like this:
There are two objects, two entities, which we will call A and B. You know only one thing, one mathematical condition: When there is A, there is also B. And that's all you know. Everything tells you that, both sensorially and logically: when you don't have proper blood supply to your arm, it goes numb: when you do have blood supply, information doesn't come from there. When something is not what it previously was with regards to the arm, then there is no consciousness: Also, then, when not A, not B. Alright, then, we have two conditions, actually: When A is, B is; when A isn't, B also isn't.
What is the mathematical solution to this logic problem?

Yeah, pretty easy.

A = B.

i kind of find saying that things need senses to be conscious an insult. what if you're deaf, blind, and paralyzed, even just for five minutes? are you basically dead? do you have no rights anymore? do you just stop existing? what state do you go in when you fall asleep? unconsciousness? do you stop existing here on earth until you wake up again? what happens when you're under anesthesia? or go into a sensory deprivation chamber? what if you have a syndrome that makes it more difficult to acknowledge how you're living? i don't know, i just don't think humans are all that special. there are so many other animals on earth that have more sensory organs and there are others that even have bodily awareness and self-recognition, like birds and dolphins. you can't just define "consciousness" as having human sensory functions, like touch, sight, taste, hearing, and vision. i believe that when all our senses get taken away, there's an unexplainable sense of being that would be impossible to describe because that would break the point of it. you can't describe consciousness because it's not supposed to be described. description is unnecessary and irrelevant to consciousness. our senses are a physical tool used to communicate and bridge consciousness to the physical state.

Very good video! A few points: A "living thing" is a neutral, non-charged term. With the term, "self" we have already entered emotionally charged territory. Recently, the theory that consciousness means "information integration" has gained notice. I would suggest that "information integration" means
"information integration", and that what we mean by "consciousness" is different. To we humans "consciousness" means being aware, but more importantly, "being aware of being aware". Now, you could say that "being aware of being aware" is part of our "information integration" if you like I suppose. But, I submit that to most of us "information integration" does not feel like a satisfactory explanation of what we mean by "consciousness" or of "being aware of being aware". If we ponder deeply "being aware of being aware" that will lead directly to an infinite regression - mirrors reflecting mirrors infinitely. I think that is a clue that what we really mean by "consciousness" lies beyond conception, and gives a strong hint that the word "consciousness" is not an appropriate one for science to use. I suggest that the the term "consciousness" is useful to teachers of traditional spiritual traditions, such as Buddhism and Hinduism, and to Jungian psychology perhaps, but not to neurologists. Like "self", it is too emotionally charged, and consequently muddies the waters of science. I think science should stick to dry, neutral terms like "information integration".

I love this video. So, some guys in orange robes have been researching this topic for a while, and their experiments and experience may shed some light. First, you must define Consciousness. Through the practice of meditation, anyone can come to experience that there are 2 types of consciousnesses - those that arise from your sensory perceptions, and a base awareness.

Upon close observation, it is experienced that our minds have a consciousness of visual perception, a consciousness of sound, a consciousness of discursive thought/speech, and so on, that immediately and simultaneously arise with the perception of those sensations. In other words, without those sensations, those consciousnesses do not exist in that moment. The hardware still exists of course, but the software doesn't launch without a trigger.

Upon the knowing/sensing, the mind then immediately processes those senses, begins to judge them, and finally takes action. If one manages to train themselves to let the mind settle down properly, one sees those sensory consciousnesses slowly wink out, one by one, until you are only aware of being aware. Awash in an infinite sea of nothingness, no thoughts, no sensations, no concepts. It is clear, like pure water. This can be called base awareness.

What gives rise to this? Simply one more piece of hardware in the brain? If so, is it part of the primordial lizard brain of our brain stem, or is it a function of the higher, more recently evolved pieces? To say the origins of consciousness lie in the evolved ability to perceive and react to the senses would perhaps imply that this second type of consciousness arose separately. But why would it? How does this kind of awareness help in survival and reproduction? Did Neanderthal ladies really dig deep discussions on reality? Or perhaps this base awareness arises as a response to the multitude of sensory information, and is like a mental space of sorts, a room with many doors, that gathers and stores these other consciousnesses and acts as an operator of information, so that when the senses are all triggered and on, we can have a coordinated perception of a single reality, a gathering of consciousnesses that we mentally meld into one, and call "Consciousness". It arises only in the presence of other consciousnesses, arising with the knowing, and disappearing only when there is nothing to be conscious of, like its siblings. Perhaps then this base awareness is simply the coordinator, the collector, or the store consciousness - a simple virtual space created by the brain to make sense of the world. If that's the case, then any organism with more than one sense may have it too. They might not be able to isolate this awareness mentally like we can, which is why we feel special.

If you have a gullible brain, it will absorb knowledge like the desert would suck up water, and it does so since it never questions the data that is fed to it. Its mind will become quite large. However, a smart brain takes a different path. This path can lead to trouble. It can for instance figure out how to create consciousness. Think of a computer program that creates conscious minds. One of these conscious minds may want to figure out what consciousness actually is. As it gets closer and closer to understanding consciousness, it is getting closer and closer to the very program in operation that is creating its consciousness in the first place. As a consequence of this, the distance between the two is diminishing, thus the mind itself is shrinking in size, all due to this catch-up.

Eventually, the mind will be reduced to a small non-stop loop. Fortunately, when this happens to a human being, the rate of neurotransmitter consumption in this loop, exceeds the rate of supply, and so you fall out of the loop. Then you spend every bit of effort that you can, to forget how consciousness works, all to get your mind back to its original size.

Back on the "Emergence" video, I had already my assumptions on the matter. To me, it's pretty simple: We can't define consciousness as an object because it is not an object, it is the collective of ideas, experiences and memories unique to each one, and it exists only on the present moment because the brain is active. We try to do it anyways because it works with beings of much lower intelligence than us (almost anything on Earth).


But since conciousness is a property of an active brain, it can't be defined by another active brain of the same kind because it would require more processing power than it has (read about the Laplace's demon). In other words, we are intelligent enough to be aware of ourselves, but only beings smarter than us would be able to emulate and embrace the full meaning of a human consciousness.

I'm no expert but here's my quick take: adult humans don't have trouble delaying gratification. This is a choice that is neurologically available to anyone (with the possible exception of people who are severely mentally disabled). When humans fail to delay gratification, it's because that choice is happening in a complex world where there are competing factors and drives, for example there is usually another human on the other end of that transaction who may or may not be relied upon to fulfill their promise of future gratification. Put a human in a stripped down lab setting like the chicken experiment, for example "you can have a dollar now or $10 in an hour" and pretty much anyone will manage to wait the hour.

This video definitionally conflates consciousness with the physical properties of an organism and its behavior. This conflation is established at the beginning of the video when a spectrum of "simple" to "complex" consciousness is posited. All that is known to become more complex are the bodies and behaviors of the organisms, not consciousness. When an organism gains senses, develops memory, or evolves physiologically in any capacity, there isn't any more consciousness "added" to the equation.

To say consciousness "evolved" is essentially to admit to a belief (yes, a belief) that consciousness is an emergent property of matter. To say that also admits to a belief (yes, a belief) that the more complex an organism is, the "more" conscious it is.

Consciousness should rather be defined as the simple, fundamental fact of experiencing, no matter how rudimentary from our point of view. Anything which we could reasonably consider to be experiencing something, anything at all, is conscious. In that sense, an insect is just as conscious as a human being. The human being is only more physiologically complex, not consciously.

Man, this was super complex, but I don't think I buy the idea of consciousness at all. It seems impossible to prove that another creature posses or lacks it. All we can do is create tests and assume based on the results; but really, those results don't tell us they lack consciousness, only that they were incapable of passing the test. In that scenario, I'd say the creature in question was lacking in intelligence, not consciousness. For example, when a child makes an action that leads to a bad consequence they were unable to predict, we wouldn't say in that scenario they lacked a certain level of consciousness- merely that the variables that would allow them to understand the consequences of their actions were not at the necessary parameters.

I have a problem with your choice of words. What you are describing in this video is not consciousness, it is adaptive behaviour patterns.
Meaning presupposes consciousness and awareness. This means that analytical reasoning or any other form of intelligence is an emerging property of consciousness, but it is not consciousness itself.
Just because we as a culture have evolved to the point of experiencing language, a self-referential but yet ever-evolving symbolic loop of logic, doesn't mean that we are any more or less aware than rocks or bacteria.

To push my point further, if the idea that experiencing and utilising language is an implication of consciousness, then it must also imply that language itself is conscious, because it is utilising our species and our culture for it's expression. That means if we are using language to become self-aware, then so is language.

You say that being able to respond to outside stimuli and delay gratification implies consciousness, well it doesn't! It implies choice! And choice in turn implies consciousness. But consciousness can exist without choice, and without language, and without adaptive behaviour patterns.

Consciousness must be the substratum of existence and life is the emerging pattern. Not the other way around.

Far as I can tell, consciousness isn't anything special. Just a natural offshoot of intelligence, which is a natural offshoot of life. We've created computer programs that run code more complex than the processes in cells, and we've created programs that rely on various inputs and a sense of memory to better achieve their goals. I don't think it's really that hard to create a program with 'consciousness', really it just sounds like a self-diagnostic function that many programs already have. We might not think of it as consciousness because it's alien to us, but that doesn't make it less valid, and you can't really tell if it's equivalent or not because you can never experience what it's like to be that computer program.

I disagree with this entire notion that consciousness is some set of discrete steps and leaps separate from intelligence. For example, the video talks about the sense of time as some crucial step. But time is already a sensory input to a neural network. The feedback structures of a neural network inherently allows for measurement of time (think of how electrical oscillators work). Small network are just not complex enough to make use of it. But I'm willing to bet if you took a small network that appears not to have the concept of time, and then increase the number of nodes and training data, it will eventually develop the ability to have states and perceive time, simply because being able to do so enables more efficient and accurate achievement of one's goals. Consciousness is just an illusion, a vast combination of learned behaviors and patterns that make us efficient. But any neural network will naturally achieve the same thing with the same number of neurons, training data, and sensory input, at least I believe so.

I love your videos, but I think this is a miss. I don't think it's oversimplified, but taking a discrete step by step approach to the evolution of consciousness is problematic. Consciousness emerges, but not just from step by step accumulation of abilities. An organism that smells, sees, and hears does not necessarily have a higher level of consciousness than one that just sees. I agree that multiple sensory methods, memory, and an understanding of time, seem to be a requirement for consciousness. Yet inferring that there's an equivalency between capabilities (sensory throughput, memory, intelligence, among others) and self awareness, misses something fundamental that results in apparent paradoxes.

For example, you imply that simply adding vision provides an organism with the capability to understand object permanence (5:04 - 5:44). Yet later you acknowledge that object permanence is not understood even by organisms that have many senses (6:00 - 6:33).

Another problem is revealed when you equate food caching with the emergence of temporal cognisance. Ants and many other insects cache food. Does the individual ant understand time in the same way as the scrub jay? What is the ant colony''s understanding of time?

As you can probably tell, I believe emergent properties explain much of what we see in the universe. Failure to explore consciousness as a manifestation of this more fundamental property resulted in a video that could be dismissed as oversimplified, but in reality is just not quite accurate.

Your definition of consciousness is too broad to connect to any specific cause. Why not start at the so-called "Human Revolution" of the Upper Paleolithic? That appears to be where human animals and other animals began to seriously diverge on this dimension. And if you do start there, you'll find that the Human Revolution seems to have been jump-started by the human formerly known as Cro Magnon, and now referred to as Early Modern European. And, if you look more closely at him, you'll find he popped into existence as the hybrid child of Homo Sapiens Sapiens and Homo Neanderthalensis.


Why is this important? Because hybrid animals have a devil of a time succeeding in the wild. First, they are usually sterile (think mules), and even when they aren't biologically sterile, they can still have overwhelming trouble securing a mate because they are just different from either parent species, and thus from potential mates. The fossil record indicates that EME moved Northward and Westward after emerging near the Levant, where hybridization was happening, likely in one-offs for tens of thousands of years. The point is that, as this new, hybrid animal struggled to survive, he succeeded, and it seems to be due to changes in consciousness forced upon him as a hybrid. He became aware of his difference from the Other. As he moved he began pulling out things from the inside and externalizing them. The emergence of material culture in humans grew from knapping stones to making jewelry and symbols. This is the birth of our form of consciousness, where we reach inside and pull out what doesn't actually exist in the world outside of us yet, and thus is not shared between us homogeneously, as a mixed-up, hybrid species. As you look around at text, tables, cars, computers, and language - and everything else we have created - understand that our need to build externally the shared world that no longer existed internally among us has been the engine behind it all.


Aside from the hybridization issue, the other main factor is what we seemingly evolved to do, which is taxonomize, breed, and perfect. Agriculture comes to emphasize this urge, and, thousands of years later, we're all born to taxonomize, and we do it all willy-nilly, applying hierarchies to things whether or not it actually makes sense to do so. That's called Vacuum Behavior by scientists, and it's when an animal performs a ritualized behavior even in the absence of the natural stimulus for that behavior. This constant need to taxonomize gives us benefits, but also troubles, like trying to taxonomize races, etc. This kind of behavior is typically non-conscious, if we take consciousness to mean awareness of awareness, and not just awareness, itself.

2 Problems:

1) The consciousness you speak of in this video is not the same consciousness as is discussed by physicists and and philosophers as "The Big Problem". What you are talking about here is simply the evolution of the senses to obtain food. It's the -ness at the end which is important in consciousness as The Big Problem, not the conscious part. Most people are conscious without experiencing any consciousness. What we're seeking to understand is how we know that we know, not that we can use our senses to explore the environment to collect food.

2) Unfortunately, you've failed to explain how unaware things "became" aware, leaving us with the inaccurate, and disappointing, conclusion that consciousness arose because of a basic need for food. If this was the direction you had intended, to find out how particles gathered and became able to be aware of themselves as a collective "I", instead of explaining consciousness itself, then you should have been focusing on the gap between inert and alive, the leap from one to the other, and the difference between them, not the evolution of senses to obtain food.

Language seems to emerged from the urge to reproduce.

Listen carefully for a spring forest. What do you hear? Insects, birds, animals -- all shouting to find a partner to reproduce. They can't do it with vision because there are a lot of obstacles in a forest and organisms tend to stick around to a territory where they feast.

But voice was not the first language. Many insects are mute and deaf but they still able to communicate via chemicals. The smell was their first language system and it still is one of the strongest. Still, many collective insects use non-verbal language to inform their nest about food sources they found as bees do.

Its simple as far as Im concerned. Consider for a moment that we let consciousness be a universal law like gravity or the speed of light. Then that would mean that consciousness is always there and always has been, but the catch is that it takes more advanced creatures to experience higher levels of it. And the experiences can only be from the creatures senses such as touch, sight, sound, or any combination of sensory perceptions with a complex enough brain to process it all. But perhaps even an atom could be conscious in terms of feeling in some way the electrons around it. I suppose this is more of a philosophical perspective but I think it makes the problem of consciousness really easy, though who knows, maybe someday we will discover an exact mechanism that causes it. But my money is still on it being a fundamental force of some kind.

Recent research into mental disorders and disabilities with dissociation at the core is at odds with Kurzgesagt explanation of basic consciousness. Consciousness is likely unique to the Homo sapiens and formed not from the evolution of new brain areas but from the establishment of new connections among old ones. The perfect example of this interconnection is why humans can't remember early development stages in life because these connections haven't been established; it takes time for sensory experiences to form memories, then for self-reflection of these memories helps create our place in time and who we are. Why is dissociation intriguing well it seems that disorders and disabilities that have it as a core symptom are likely linked to problems with specific brain areas failing to communicate effectively together? This leads to the symptom of the disconnected self or unreality lower form of consciousness. Newer Areas of scientific research like neuroplasticity reinforce this new research but its still early days.

There is still a hard problem of consciousness. Why do we need the subjective experience? We could have evolved to become like speaking ants, perfect social communication but no space for individuality.

I wish you could explain how it works better though, rather than why it works. Unfortunately trying to understand how consciousness works is like trying to look inward at your eyes without a mirror or  a snake trying to eat itself from its tail into nothing. It may be simple, but because we are consciously trying to understand consciousness it is difficult if not impossible to "wrap ones mind" around it. It also seems unintuitive and illogical to say that the "cause and effect" of the laws of physics and matter, even at complex levels, can create the sense of "feeling". Does a Rube Goldberg machine feel anything, no matter how complex? No, but somehow we know that we are conscious and we don't know why.  I really wish we could though. People are smart, maybe we will someday. But for now pretty good explanation of why it works.

Consciousness (obvious to me) originated at the connection point of senses (inputs) and motor functions (outputs), providing more flexibility in prospective responses, which increased the odds of finding nutrients (and then later avoiding predators and finding mates). The biological program was simple (and still is for lower lifeforms): TOWARD, AWAY, IGNORE.

Now we are at 'intelligence', which originated during idle time (also obvious to me), and which added two more commands to nature's bio-program: CONTEMPLATE and MANIPULATE. Some lifeforms became cleverer than others, and some specialized in cleverness. Humans are at the top of cognitive cleverness (again, obvious to me).

Now we are at 'enlightenment', meaning philosophical enlightenment, and intelligence and cleverness do not automatically equate with enlightenment. Take humans, for example. They are intelligent and clever, but they are also still unenlightened (enter me and my philosophy, which offers Final Enlightenment - go read it). Another name for an intelligent and clever being that is not yet enlightened is "a loose cannon", since being unenlightened is another name for 'cluelessness' which is blindly destructive (hence the 'loose cannon' comparison).


In summary, 'consciousness' began as a centralized destination for our various senses (though the brain has many independent parts, and is not technically 'centralized'). What we refer to as 'consciousness' is this reception center of senses. No big mystery. Later, evolution favored those brains that offered more flexibility in motor outputs - i.e. those outputs that are no longer 'hard-wired', where the hard-wiring bypasses the brain - we still have hard-wiring - we call them 'reflexes' - they offer no flexibility - they are singular in their outputs, and their advantage is 'speed' - we need not waste time contemplating what output to choose from.

Some people argue that the universe has some kind of counsciousness since it interacts with itself through its own laws. Some say that it has a spirit, or say that we humans have a spirit, or that we and animals have a spirit; and therefore consciousness. But there is no way of proving so. Language is sometimes taken as ´The Human Esence´, since it allow us to talk about an infinite amount of things we want to talk. Those who say so have the idea that language involves having cosciousness of the existence <del>or non existence-</del> of things, and that the use of words creates a creative mind. Several scientific approaches have been developed to study language, and many ideas have came out to explain the linguistic phenomenon since ancient times. Sign language,  invented languages and codes, other species ways of communication, and many other things related to the study of language are the scope of many different sciences, as biology, neuroscience, linguistics, anthropology or literary studies. Linguistics is a very broad science nowadays. Noam Chomsky and B.F. Skinner are seen as the main characters in the study of language, but many, maany ideas and ways of studying language and literature have been raised up. Terrence Deacon wrote on his book The Symbolic Species that we humans have a special faculty that he calls symbolic thinking. He argues that only humans have language, and that no language, no consciousness. On the other hand, Yuval Harari says in his book Sapiens that most animals have some kind of language. Our language basis is the use of signs and rules, but also many other species language. Thus, the only difference between us and other animals is that in our species happened what is called the Cognitive Revolution, which brought many language developments, as gossiping or  the invention of fictive stories as those of gods or human rights. The question of what language is and what  it involves in the human species is not easy to answer, but language is undoubtably an important part of consciousness at many levels of life forms, since it involves that organisms require communication for the recognition of some kind of signal to understand some kind of information given by another organism, not necessarily of the same species. Communication enables the interaction among organisms, as well as knowing or recognizing other organisms existence and taking them as friendly or dangerous. Here some information about social organisms most be taken into account. Maybe we did not have our consciusness level when we started using words to communicate. A theory says that we first acquired the control of some parts of our digestive and respiratory systems, allowing us to transform our thoughts into words. I think that every organism has some kind of consciousness. Our brain evolved and connected language with intelligence; Broca´s and Wernicke´s areas with the prefontal cortex, making us the Intelligent Life of this planet.

Problem 1: a sense of smell is "perception at a distance". Vision is not special in this regard.

Problem 2: the first part of the video is implying that consciousness requires context from environmental stimuli. I agree, actually, but that's far from a settled issue. It does seem that processing of environmental context is what we call "consciousness", but if that's true, would a human brain that was, from the start, cut off from all external signals, have consciousness? It's not currently possible to say.

Problem 3: The idea that words are an essential part of what we would recognize as consciousness is a huge assumption. Not just because that assumption makes it impossible for us to recognize consciousness in a species that, say, communicates primarily through olfactory cues, but also because language as we know it is a distinctly human phenomenon.

Panpsychism was definitely misrepresented in this video. It's not that "rocks" have consciousness, it's that atoms and whatever other material building blocks there are in the universe have some base level of consciousness. And some combination of these particles can "amplify" this consciousness feature in regular matter to create more complex versions of consciousness, but the form matters. (Like a brain, for example.)

At the base of panpsychism, it is realized that the Jump from non-concious particles to consciousness can't be explained, and therefore it assumes as a "brute fact" that consciousness to some very small degree exists in all particles, and then further deduces that more complex consciousnesses are the result of evolution strategically creating a form over time that amplifies this already existing quality. In the case of rocks, the form is not amplifying the existing consciousness in each particle, so it (as a rock) is no more conscious than a grain of sand, or anything else. You could break it apart and you wouldn't be "killing" the consciousness of the rock or anything silly like that.

It's the view that my philosophy professor held in university, and it's a view I feel is most likely as well (given the paradoxes that arise from any other assumption).

Also, the given explanation for consciousness in the video doesn't explain why we have any "phenomenological experience" associated with using our senses, as opposed to just chasing food like a computer with an evolutionarily designed survival program running would. Evolution could have created "programs" that explain everything described in the video but without there being an internal experience (qualia) associated with the program.

This video seems to miss the mark on the consciousness discussion entirely. See "zombie universe" to learn more about the problem this video has failed to mention.

I can't wait for the next video on consciousness. :) An interesting point is that while we know from observation that as newborns we go through a phase in which we lack object permanence (hence the game of peek-a-boo), we don't actually remember it ourselves once we do become conscious. Our memory of our own consciousness tends to start at around two years. Infants still react to stimuli and the world around them, but they don't remember it later on. It almost seems that we start with a sort of basic neural template that lends itself to developing self-awareness, but doesn't start out self-aware, and of course the human template is primed to develop language, which is part of what makes us so freakish. Things like object permanence or tool use have been done before, but human languages seem genuinely unique.

I just want to say that panpsychism (1:58), as a philosophical term, had been conceived and defined in different ways by many thinkers through the years. The best example of that can be found in the book "Panpsychism in the West" by David Skrbina. Skrbina himself criticized the usage of the "rock" example to describe panspychism. He also offered a different perspective based on a larger definition of consciousness. He wrote: "Upon laying out a panpsychist position, one is immediately faced with the charge that he believes that “rocks are conscious”—a statement taken as so obviously ludicrous that panpsychism can be dismissed out of hand. (...) To overcome this anthropocentric perspective, the panpsychist asks us to see the “mentality” of other objects not in terms of human consciousness but as a subset of a certain universal quality of physical things, in which both inanimate mentality and human consciousness are taken as particular manifestations" (p.17).


Basically, from a larger definition of panpsychism, consciousness does not randomly appears through the process of evolution, but it is a manifestation of a more fundamental aspect of reality. It is intertwined with matter and everything that is. In that perspective, consciousness is somewhat ambient. It is simply experienced differently by different "receptacles". In that way, we humans possess a more fine-tuned receptacle (our body) to experience certain aspect of consciousness that a rock could never experience. If the rock did indeed experience something, it would be an experience so foreign to human understanding that it would complicate the picture presented at 1:58.


Therefore, from this panpsychist's point of view, the debates around consciousness shouldn't be limited to the only resulting behaviour that we are able to observe (the act of being conscious), but should be open to more philosophical questions around the nature of consciousness. In short, panpsychist uses a much wider definition of consciousness than is normally used. Since consciousness still and will remain a scientific mystery, the philosophical questions and perspectives proposed by panspsychists have withstood the test of time and are still relevant today.


The important thing to remember here is that the term "panspychism" itself does not possess a singular definition, but is often re-interpreted. No ones believe that rocks have the same level or quality of consciousness as humans, that would be insane.

All that was explained was "how" consciousness is used, not where it came from or the mechanism that produces it. I enjoyed the citation of scientific articles. The video adopts the category error made by these papers that consciousness must be defined in terms of physical function. Doing so ignores the hard problem of consciousness which is the reality that science currently cannot explain what physical mechanism produces consciousness. This means that either consciousness is not purely physical or that consciousness requires a scientific knowledge beyond what we presently have. In either case, this evolutionary theory explains the use of consciousness by organisms, but not the origin of consciousness.

It's a big leap to assume that consciousness is an evolved trait, or even that it is inherently linked to intelligence at all. The ability to experience (which is as good a definition of consciousness as any) does not have any requirement that it's tied to the ability to process that experience coherently, and the reasons for arguing that it is are frankly tenuous.

Even if it is a trait that stems from increasingly complexity, I feel like this whole video equates consciousness to thinking or to decision making, which just isn't justified. If it were as simple as that, then we wouldn't have had such trouble with it in the first place.

I think it was a mistake to only put forward one very particular school of thought like this, because it doesn't really explore the issue properly.

Still love your videos, mind! But I have a few issues with this particular one.

What the!?!? The assertion that consciousness is but the emergent result of the firing of billions of neurons is an assertion without a scrap of evidence that must be believed, but cannot be demonstrated. If your brain (from which flows consciousness, mind, and all that relates) is merely the end product of mindless, unintentional actions by impersonal forces in a strictly materialistic universe that is unguided and ungoverned, then why do you trust it? If you knew that your home computer was the end product of the same, then you wouldn’t trust it for a minute! In fact, if that were actually the case, then you wouldn’t have a computer at all, but merely a mass of disjointed and unintelligible collection of parts.

We may be able to put all of the chemicals used in our brains to control emotion into a bowl and add electricity, but we can never say that the bowl loves us. There is something more to knowing "truth" than merely that which can be shown to us through observational science; what logical positivists (strict empiricists) need to understand is that science is not the only means at our disposal to investigate reality.

TBH the whole issue not covered is insects. For example an ant. Just by itself ant has no consciousness and is as stupid as it gets. But put it in a colony and suddenly the sheer level of consciousness skyrockets. I observed similar behavior from beekeeping. An individual bee has no thought, but the second you have a colony of bees, then suddenly all bees start acting as one single unit and additionally each bee seems to have consciousness too. Even if you hide something from sight, the bees that saw the object being hidden will cause every single other bee to instantly know that object is hidden and they will be able to retrieve it. If for example you take one bee that is capable of performing a certain task (digging, pulling, lifting) and you take another bee that incapable of performing such task. The second you put those two bees together, the bee that was incapable of performing said task gains the skill necessary to do so. I still can not wrap my mind how the heck that even is possible. It is as if those insects have consciousness on a whole another level. If Kurzgesagt is interested I can provide videos of things said above.

This is an interesting video. However, I think we don't need to be aware to do all of that. If we are just a bunch of atoms, and these atoms arrange themselves in a way that helps them survive, there is no need for whatever object they form to be aware, and our nervous system and response to stimuli isn't due to awareness. For example, if a person has their hand near a fire, their nervous system will respond immediately, moving their hand away. The human does not need to think "my hand is in the fire, the fire is denaturing proteins in my hand, they will not function properly and I must, therefore, move away before too much damage is done". It's the same with memory. Signals can arrange themselves into the patterns that will trigger neurons in the brain the same way, causing an organism to respond in a similar fashion. A being without consciousness can, therefore, learn and evolve.
It could reproduce whenever physically ready, using the same patterns and learning techniques to recognise potential mates and danger. It could even be argued that this is more efficient. There is no need for thought, no need for morals or hopes or dreams or curiosity or sorrow. There will only be time and space to survive. And yet, here we are.

Beginning with the premise of this video we are dealing with an illogical presumption. Negatives cannot and do not add up into positives. Claiming that things are unaware(negatives) and at some point became aware(positives) is, in my opinion, irrational mathematics and simply does not add up. So, let's watch the video.
Ahh, the title is somewhat deceptive. For the record, not all panpsychics(me for one) do not equate consciousness with life-which is the ability to self-organize and reproduce. Rocks are not self-organizing nor do they reproduce. But, plasma as in an ionizing gas is self-organizing and interestingly constitutes 99.9% of the visible universe. What makes plasma self-organizing is electric charge denoted as Q+(masculine energy) and Q-(feminine energy).
Energy, the narrator states is what is required to reproduce and this true and I suspect he is now going to avoid discussing the description laid out in the title.
@2:45 he says, "On the smaller scales of life you don't need to be aware to find food" and then talks about Trichopax adhaerens and claims that they move around haphazardly, but speed up where there is no food and slows down where there is food. He then suggests that it is not conscious of its environment and this is in direct contradiction of what he just said. If it speeds up where there is no food and slows down where there is food, it is clearly conscious of its immediate environment. He assumes that because it does not make a straight line to a particular destination it is not conscious and that is a fallacious argument. A blind person lost in a desert will wander around in circles. A limited perception does not equate to a lack of consciousness. He then goes on to suggest that it is the search for food that is the birth of consciousness. Thus making this a clickbait title as all he is doing is discussing the evolution of consciousness within what is considered living things.


As I stated previously, plasma is self-organizing and this is due to charge. At a very basic primordial, if not even sub-primordial level charge is aware. Like charges repel and opposite charges attract. The narrator might argue that this is not consciousness but an automatic response, which if we were to accept this then all life is merely an automatic response and honestly, when I look at humanity, homo sapien sapiens, what I see is a species constantly reacting and unaware of why they are reacting thus falsifying the claim we are conscious of our consciousness. But, this is a generalization of "mob/mass" behaviour and does not reflect all individuals. Some of us can rationalize either linearly or spacially. Therefore if we are conscious, then that consciousness can only arise upon layers of highly simplistic consciousness from a sub-primordial level to the complex level all higher orders of life exhibit to the highly complex level of homo sapiens sapiens.

I don't believe that humans evolved from any other creature.

Why is it that all answers to questions about evolution is “well we’re already here and we already have it, so it must have developed eventually after millions of years and millions of tries. And we know that it happened because we’re and we have it!”

And if you think that’s a oversimplification, every genuine question I’ve ever had ends with the answer, “over millions of years it EVENTUALLY developed”. But...Eventually? You mean no one knows how long exactly? Well duh. If we wanted to prove evolution, (micro or macro) it simply takes thousands of years for any significant changes to happen, so it’s impossible to replicate in a lab or in nature at this very moment.
How convenient.
But that’s not scientific.

Look, I’m not discounting it all as a possibility, but there’s already a problem inherent to those answers.

Because the important happenings of history and development are always so long ago, (thousands, millions, etc.), to say we know for certain is claiming much with very little, and it places the burden of proof in an unlockable safe that could only be opened with a time machine.

Oh boy this is awful. It's the second sentence and it's already wrong. Better text-react to the whole thing now...but before I do that:
If you really want to learn about consciousness, here are some places to start:
Read the "Philosophy of Mind" Wikipedia entry - lots of great info there
To learn about Illusionism: Illusionism as a Theory of Consciousness - by Keith Frankish
To learn about Materialism/Physicalism: Consciousness Explained - by Daniel Dennett
To learn about how neuroscience views the problem: Anything by Anil Seth or Christof Koch
To learn about Panspychism: read the Wikipedia or Stanford Encyclopedia entries
To learn about Mysterianism: look at the Wikipedia entry and then the books by Colin McGinn
To learn about contemporary idealism: Google search for Bernardo Kastrup
To learn about approaches in Eastern philosophy (Buddhism, Hinduism): read the Upanishads
To learn about western religious forms of interactionist dualism (souls, etc.): well...this stuff is all over the place

That should get you started.

So back to the video. Consciousness is not best described as what "allows us to have awareness". That statement is actually literally false, because you can have consciousness without awareness. Awareness itself is perhaps one part of conscious experience, but at base consciousness just means that something has "experiences". Another way to phrase it is that "it feels like something" to be conscious.

"There are no grounds for [the assumption that panpsychism it true]". What?? Do you think an entire sub-field of philosophy with thousands of academic proponents would hold a belief when there are no grounds for it? Of course there are grounds for believing it. Those grounds do not include the "behavior" of the rock, as the video uselessly points out. There are many other reasons though, which it might be good to outline, rather than simply dismissing it out of hand.

The rest of the video is just superfluous. Describing the eating and hunting habits of organisms is not an explanation of the origin of consciousness. All of the sensory abilities described in this video could easily exist within an unconscious machine. Giving an organism photoreceptors might cause their hunting behavior to become more accurate, but that does not in any way explain why it feels like something to be that organism. The origin of that feeling is left totally untouched by the entire video, even though that is the thing it purports to explain. This video should simply be re-titled: The Origin of Sensory Behaviors.

I was planning on commenting before actually listening to the video, at first I was going to say "this is an easy one", and had my comment ready.

But then I decided to listen, and to my surprise, this actually brings up some of the points I was going to make. To summarize.

Consciousness through the senses. One of my favorite philosophers makes this point, Alan Watts. He states "We invoke like into the world, if there were no eyes, light simply wouldn't exist." Which is a paraphrase. However, it essentially makes the point. Consciousness through awareness, or the senses. If we could not smell, how could we know what roses smelt like? If we cannot see, how would we know what the color red is? You get the point I'm making.

Our senses make up our consciousness. They make us aware and capable of navigating the difficult plain of existence we live in, even things like emotion, add an extra layer to our conscious being, like empathy, a complex social skill that gives us the ability to empathize with others and make us aware of the emotions of others.

I think something even more difficult that trying to explain Consciousness, is trying to explain what a specific color looks like, to someone who is color blind. Because the only way to do it, is to use our experiences and understandings of what a specific color is, to explain what that color is, but that person will never truly understand what that color is.

For example, I have a co-worker who is red green color blind. Even if I went as far as to explain what particular wave length the color red is, he still will not actually know, because it's an experience we gained through our senses. We became conscious of it through those senses.
If we went from simple consciousness to complex consciousness can we eventually become ultra conscious?
In conclusion, I think therefore I am, and I think because I'm hungry.

Everything a human experiences is gathered through senses such as vision and hearing. When we experience things from the world around us through our senses they are relayed to the brain where they are comprehended. However, despite receiving sensory input from the physical world; the one we actually experience is within our minds. We in a way live within our own worlds that are our minds. Again, to recap: There is a physical world that we are receiving sensory data from. However, that data is transfered to our brain in which we comprehend it. Since we are comprehending that data within our minds the world we experience is within our minds.

Also as far as I remember... We receive sensory data after it actually happens. Very miniscule amount of time after but still not the exact time it happens. So it's kind of like you're receiving a delayed live feed. And if you're not technically experiencing the world exactly when it happens then... ^

Maybe I have to watch the other 2 parts, but I think maybe a focus on unconsciousness might yield better results. I was in a coma for a week and it was the best thing I have ever not experienced. Not too hot or cold, not too dry or wet, not too light or dark, it was perfect. Try it sometime if you get the chance. Mine was as a result of a head on collision between a big truck and my small, two door hatch, only doing about 50 to 60 Km/h each. The steering wheel hit me in the chin and on the chest, pinned me against the chair before the chair broke and by back did too, L4 vertebra compacted and fractured but I can still walk just fine, "severe brain damage" according to two doctors and some scans also a cleanly broken right tibia (must've been relaxed, fear is for the weak LOL) I haven't felt much pain, and the brain damage only made me smarter albeit more forgetful. I can't remember the day of the accident, but independent eye witness reports lead me to believe, as soon as my car stopped about 100 meters from the truck, I got out and ran "in record time" to the truck and "abused the driver incoherently", I wandered back in the direction of my car, kept going in that direction until I collapsed in a field 200 to 300 meters in that direction, the same field that the rescue helicopter landed in, they induced the coma before I could enjoy the free ride.  I 'can' remember some of the coma, I spoke while I was in a coma. My brother came in to identify my body, I heard his voice say "Yes, that's my brother." I spoke up saying "Yes, that's Leon, my brother." trying to get him to pretend to be me because I was worried that my licence may have expired recently. LOL He didn't get it and told them who I was, a while after I had woken up, I told him about it and he goes, "Yeah, we heard you talking in your coma." The day I woke up from the coma, all I could think about was the opening scene from "Resident Evil" where Milla wakes up in a hospital bed. I pulled out my ventilator and tore up my vocal chords, (couldn't talk louder than a whisper for 10 months after that) I pulled out my catheter still inflated, said "F**K THAT HURTS!" My mother saw this and said "I bet it does", next were the long thin steel things in my chest and as soon as I pulled those out I tried getting up. Everyone jumped and tried to keep me in the bed, but there was blood squirting out of my chest, so I squirted people in the face, waiting a bit for next heartbeat to give me another go at someone else, eventually I made it to the door, looked out and saw four security guards walking down the hall toward me, I thought "f**k this I'm going back to that bed." turned around, took one step and collapsed unconscious because not enough blood was getting to my brain. I spent 11 months all up in hospital, it was like a holiday where girls dressed as nurses hand feed you and give you a sponge bath whenever you need one. Positive thinker, signing off. LOL

The big what if here is the supposition that there are some objective qualities in consciousness itself. Without such objective qualities, there cannot be an evolution, since something that has no properties or qualities cannot evolve, since it is always the same - transparent and without qualities. And all "qualities" that we might ascertain to consciousness ARE in themselves objects in consciousness so they cannot define consciousness itself.


So where is the proof that it evolved? Without that, the entire argument is moot, based on unproven premises.

Consciousness should be viewed from 2 standpoints - 1) technical side 2) existential side.
Technical side contains questions like "what properties of our brain allow this phenomena?" etc
Existential side is basically the basis nihilism - consciousness is something that lets me know I exist, but does anything else actually exist, I don't know. Maybe every object has its own consciousness (it can't think, but it can be in its own way), or maybe just I.

I can't help but feel that there is some conflation going on here between intelligence and consciousness. The core issue with consciousness in philosophy is in a sense that it's not clear why all the reproductive abilities that you mention in this video would need a creature to be conscious - have an experience of 'what it is like' to be - on top of their other abilities.

For instance, a creature arguably needs some sensory apparatus and information processing systems to be succesful. However, having that is not the same as being conscious. A heat-seeking missile has a sensory apparatus that allows it to locate its target, and a complex algorithm that allows it to be intelligent in some regard in navigating to hit its target. However, it would be very controversial to say that the missile is conscious to any degree in virtue of these abilities.

The same puzzle goes for humans. In order to survive we seem to need information gathering systems (e.g. vision) and information processing (i.e. intelligence), but it's not clear why we couldn't have those without qualitative experiences (i.e. consciousness) on top of that. (This is the philosophical thought experiment of "zombies", see the Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy article you link to).

You might well answer that it's just a law of nature that at some level of combination of intelligence and sensory impressions consciousness will emerge. But that's highly non-trivial (even if I'm sympathetic to it), and I don't feel that you said anything similar in this video to support claims about consciousness specifically.

Yes, but none of this really goes to the core of consciousness, which is the actual experience. You could make a computer program do a version of all these things — get data from the environment, have an inner state which updates based on events, making decisions based on both the inner state and the data from the environment, and so on — but it's still not actually conscious. Consciousness does indeed aquire and process information, but what makes a consciousness and consciousness is the subjective experience. You might say it's the specific method by which to do the information processing, and not the information processing itself. Computers uses another method.

I have some issues with this video. It tries to explain what consciousness is by taking examples of behaviors in the animal kingdom. But the link between behavior and consciousness is assumed and not proven. Kudzgezagt cited no behavior as proof of no consciousness in a rock, but i fail to see how behavior does prove consciousness. For example, the birds who hide food in a delayed manner don't require empathy to other souls, if they evolved through natural selection to apply this behavior. They act on instinct, and instinct is typically defined as "unconscious behavior". Further, advanced machines can be much better at complicated behavior but you would agree they are not conscious.

Some philosophers / scientists believe that language is one of the necessary ingredients of consciousness. In this regard, the part of the video that would be wrong is the part where you say it's a gradient scale. The argument is that language allows us to make concrete our mental representions. Research shows that children raised by wolves are cognitively impaired, and they remain that way if 'saved' too late.

But maybe the issue is also philosophical. Because you use 'consciousness' as if it just means 'awareness' but you also use it in different ways. It shows we can't explain consciousness, because by definition we can only ever know what our own consciousness is like. So you can never define it. In this way, it's a qualia - something that you can only truly understand by experiencing it (like colour)
