I have to disagree, to an extent. I don't think that hunger was the only driving factor in conciousness. I believe it was 1 of 3 aspects.

The primary need in conciousness is survival. Which would be encompassed by these 3 things. Hunger, sex and lifespan.

The first rule is hunger. As displayed in this video.

The second is reproduction/sex. Which requires a basic drive to continue a specie. In most reproductive processes, there are chemical processes required. The exception being one celled critters which only require food to split. I pretty sure that as the complexity of reproduction became more and more involved, the need to be conscious of those circumstances would need to be raised. We call it an inate desire but it is still a conscious effort to actually go out and do the deed, which would require in the very minimum, a degree of memory, conciousness and social capability. All the way up to humans which I'd wager have some of the most complex mating rituals.

Then there's the life cycle of a specie. Obviously, most critters have a rather low lifespan and it shows in everything else they do ranging from unawareness of their surroundings to failure to adapt to being outcast in favor of a new evolutionary step. When a creature evolves it is based on those 3 aspects. Hunger, sex and overall lifespan. Which is why so many creatures have some level of what we define as conciousness. It is a necessary evolutionary step to develop the awareness of your surroundings, to remember where food and breeding grounds are and to ensure the best survival rates possible which include things such as camouflage, stealth, cardio, hibernation, etc etc etc. Unless you're higher on the food tier. While camouflage and stealth is still key, speed, viciousness, hunting/tracking is more required. Being conscious of possible repercussions and defense strategies.

Then there's us. Conciousness in unison with perception and intelligence led to tools, medicine, structures and mastery of every aspect of survival. Even venturing into sustaining lifespans almost 3x the length of our ancestors.

Question being, what do we do to evolve beyond where we are today? The answer is simple and that's why so many are against it. The natural process for us is to become less conscious in order to evolve.

Think about it. We have become so divided as a civilization that we are incapable of moving onto the next step. Yes, we have brilliant individuals on this planet that invent extraordinary things but it's nothing compared to what we could do if every person were working in unison to overcome our home planet and venture into space in search of new homes.

OSHO >> Modern physics has discovered one of the greatest things ever discovered, and that is: matter is energy. Even the solid rock is a pulsating energy, even the solid rock is as much energy as the roaring ocean. Your body is energy, your mind is energy, your soul is energy. Then what is the difference between these three? The difference is only of a different rhythm, different wavelengths, that's all. The body is gross ¯ energy functioning in a gross way, in a visible way.

When you are tremendously happy with yourself, happy as you are, blissful as you are, grateful as you are, and all your energies are dancing together, when you are an orchestra of all your energies, the divine is. That feeling of total unity is what the divine is. The divine is not a person somewhere, The divine is the experience of the three falling in such unity that the fourth arises. And the fourth is more than the sum total of the parts.

If you dissect a painting, you will find the canvas and the colors, but the painting is not simply the sum total of the canvas and the colors; it is something more. That "something more" is expressed through the painting, the color, the canvas, the artist, but that "something more" is the beauty. Dissect the rose flower, and you will find all the chemicals and things it is constituted of, but the beauty will disappear. It was not just the sum total of the parts, it was more.

The whole is more than the sum total of the parts. It expresses itself through the parts but it is more. To understand that it is more is to understand the divine. The divine is that more, that plus. It is not a question of theology; it cannot be decided by logical argumentation. You have to feel beauty, you have to feel music, you have to feel dance. And ultimately you have to feel the dance in your body, mind and, soul. You have to learn how to play on these three energies so that they all become an orchestra. Then the divine is ¯ not that you see it; there is nothing to be seen. The divine is the ultimate seer, it is witnessing. -- osho

Nice video about how the CONTENTS of consciousness varies from simple to complex, but it doesn't really address why these internal representations (simple or complex) have a subjective feel to them.
I don't think most people would be tempted to say the typical AI in a video game is conscious because the AI has representations that correspond to you, other players, the game environment ("food", "obstacles") or even itself. If we said that we thought an AI, or any other agent, was conscious.. we would probably mean that we thought it had subjective experience - i.e. that there was an answer to the question "what is it like to be X?". That is one of the most common definitions of consciousness in philosophy.
There's nothing wrong with using other definitions, but for clarity I think this divergence from one of the most popular definitions should at least have been noted.

I wouldn't dismiss panpsychism so easily - explaining the emergence of consciousness is a difficult thing. What property, for instance, do certain physical things have that makes them 'consciousness.' More specifically, what combination of physical substances would lead to the development of a desire for food, and how does this occur? If consciousness is a fundamental property of everything, then perhaps it is merely certain biological structures that add a further capacity for more complex thoughts.

I am not an expert on this topic, but I think that this video oversimplifies a rather profound philosophical issue.

I had to get up halfway through the video to turn off my little space heater because I was getting too hot, and it struck me that consciousness might've evolved out of a need to be COMFORTABLE as much as out of a need to eat/gain energy. The things which evolved adaptations to be comfortable in more than one specific environment (thermal regulation, food/energy gathering, secured reproduction prospects) then would've had the resources available to develop a more advanced consciousness, because their primary concern was no longer just finding enough food.

If humans had NEVER figured out how to meet our most basic needs in a reliable way, we probably wouldn't have evolved enough to question what consciousness is. With the ever-present need for food and comfort mostly taken care of, it freed up time for us to develop other cognitive skills, like speech, writing, tool making, and...thinking too much.

To clarify, in Buddhism you have five sense faculties (eye, ear, nose, touch, mind) that are located roughly where the sense organ is while they are two different things. The so-called faculties inform the respective consciousness (sight, smell, hearing, touch, mind). At a given time all the consciousnesses together form a moment of consciousness. The quality of consciousness is that it is aware. In Buddhist philosophy it may be seen futile to attempt to read more into it. It is seen as a false perception what we usually believe to be real.
One small example: if there was an object that makes us angry, we perceive it as source of anger. This, however, is not ultimately true. If something truly were a source of anger. Everybody would get irritated by it at all times. The underlying problem is that we believe everything we are aware of to be ultimately the way we see it.

This is a great explanation of knowledge and the development of sophisticated models of the world, but I think it does little to address actual subjective consciousness. When I say consciousness, I mean the subjective experience of being. It is like something to be you. It doesn't matter for this conversation what the experiences inside consciousness are, what matters is whether there exists a conscious space to facilitate experience in the first place. What's important is not what it's like to be something, but whether it is like anything to be that thing in the first place. The intro to this video led me to believe we are talking about the same thing here. If we're not, then my criticism is just that this video uses the word "consciousness" to describe cognition.

That human consciousness evolved from a simpler consciousness seems a reasonable claim which may well be true, but there is no way to substantiate it. We can't even prove that, say, a chimp is conscious, much less that a lizard is in some way less conscious than us. What would it mean to be less conscious? Consciousness may well be binary; either the lights are on or they aren't. What are often referred to as "altered states of consciousness" are really "altered contents of consciousness". Maybe the world feels far away; maybe everything feels fuzzy and ill-defined; maybe things are clearer than they've ever been before. In any case that I've come across, the things that are altered are within consciousness. It still feels like something to be you. The lights are still on.

There is no way currently to show that any of the developments presented in this video necessitate an inner life-- that is, we could imagine a machine which exhibits these behaviors but does not have any subjective experience. A camera can see the world, but we generally attribute to it the same level of consciousness we attribute to a rock. A computer can build a model of a complex world, but I don't expect it to have any experience of the world of Skyrim. For that matter, I can't prove that you're not a philosophical zombie yourself. The only mind whose existence I can prove is my own.

I'd like to reiterate that I really liked this video! I'm only concerned about conflating consciousness and cognition. Maybe they work hand in hand, maybe they're exactly the same. I'm just saying we don't know for sure.

I believe that consciousness is simply not a construct thing, either you are not conscious or you are, but more of a spectrum. Robots could be considered a type of "consciousness" even though they are pre-programmed to act in predictable ways. The line between unconscious things and conscious things is VERY blurry. Are viruses alive? It is not clear, and thinking like consciousness is a hard grounded thing and not a type of spectrum, is a human thing to do.
All humans are just REALLY complicated machines. More complicated than any robot we have made. More complicated than bacteria or viruses. But, that does not mean we are not alive. Everything is made of the same stuff, being alive is more of an opinion. If we tried hard enough, we could make a robot we would consider alive. If you make a robot that can move around in pre-determined ways, using cameras and other programming to recreate senses, is the robot alive? Yes. Just on a lower point of the spectrum than humans.
Add more senses and abilities, and it becomes more conscious.
Of course, this is just my opinion.

I feel like at 6:50 when they talk about the chicken being able to visualize a greater reward in the future is a little bit of a jump from reason. I don't know exactly how it went, but for me, it seems like a chicken can't actually visualize that they will get more food and consciously (on some level) choose the future, but rather just learns from repetition and positive and negative feedback that they should wait if they want more food. The Narrator phrases it like the chicken is smart enough to choose within themselves that they should wait to receive a reward. I don't think that a chicken can "hold back" because they "know" they will receive more food by waiting. They're not visualizing the reward and making the intelligent decision to wait. It's not being patient or clever, it's just learned through conditioning that they will get more food. Surely the experiment points out how chickens are capable of being trained but to call it a step towards consciousness, I think, is quite the leap.

Sorry. I know this nit-picky and the point of an "in the nutshell" video isn't to overanalyze things; the jump in reasoning just bothered me. And the recent coffee break video mentioning pop science is a point to be made. I hope people don't think they understand consciousness after video but just an understanding of it "in a nutshell".

Well, this didn't tell us anything we didn't already know. Consciousness evolved. And it's beneficial. But the underlying nature of What consciousness is, matters. The question isn't how it came to be, but why we aren't philosophical zombies. Why we are able to be aware of our choices. Because the behaviours we exhibit don't inherently imply consciousness. A computer could be programmed to act the same as a human. Consciousness is a different thing from complex bahaviour. It's experienced; not exhibited.

You make the distinction early on that consciousness and intelligence are not the same. Then you present intelligent behaviors as evidence of consciousness. The problem is, we only know that we are conscious so we assume that other things like us are as well. People, animals, etc. But we actually don’t have any evidence to show that people are any more conscious than those rocks. And it’s also worth noting that science shows us that our brains actually hallucinate our entire reality, so it may be a stretch to say anything is conscious.

The assumption underlying this video is that conciousness comes from the pattern of information housed by a creature's conglomeration of neurons (commonly, the "brain"), which is a large leap since science has not found any evidence of this to be the case. There are nothing but hypotheses on the subject.

I understand they acknowledge this, but I see no use in trying to promote one's own hypothesis on a particular matter that is impossible to provide evidence on. I enjoy kurzgesagt videos when they provide useful information based on factual studies, not what they "believe to be most likely" to an impossible to answer question. There may be some degree of jumping to "anthropomorphic" levels of cognitive functions at some points, where perhaps the adaptation can be explained by a pure behavioral tendency or drive, devoid of the mental representations or complexities we have when we do something similar. Along the lines of some of the presentation, we could say that cats know their feces stink, that it would potentially attract predators, that they could reduce the smell by burying... but all that is seriously put into doubt when we observe cats trying to bury their feces on solid ground, making completely "robotic" and useless burying movements, not dragging anything with their paws.


I do not intend to suggest it's all a human thing... but it's certainly difficult, if not impossible, to assess to which degree our mental procedures have "homologies" in other animals. In fact, the observations on split-brain patients arguably suggest that even much of what we do is more mechanical, and much of our apparent conscious volition is just a post-hoc confabulation/rationalization of what we are doing by cruder inner behavioral drives.

I can get behind this, this is nice. To begin:

I have hypothesized that all humans are blank slates. Growing up, we collect knowledge around us and add things onto that slate, such as where we come from, what we like and we think this is who we are, our "Identity" so to speak, but in the end, we are always technically blank (with a little storage box somewhere for a few things). I know there is always a chance of outliers now, such as people with disabilities and people who are chemically just made up differently (I don't prefer the taste of sweet stuff, but you might), but we all have that base, blank, starting point.

Just think about it, when we need to change, such as gaining skills for a job, or want to remember something about someone, we add it to the slate. When we go without using it for a long time, the slate degrades the knowledge over time and we "forget" what it was we wanted to remember. Humor is another one of my favorite examples, as I remember a time when I didn't understand jokes. I never even knew what a joke was at the time or why it was "humorous" to some. I learned what irony was eventually and that is why I laugh now (as long as I can understand the joke). Statistically, there is such a low chance that an event could happen that when it does, SPLOOSH dopamine shot!

This brings me to how perception can be a funny thing.
If we perceive something as good but think it dosen't happen very often, when it does, we are amazed and joyous.
If we perceive something as bad but think it happens all the time, we are upset and negative.

Always remember, you may not be able to control what happens around you but you can control your response to it.
Hope I get to discuss things like this in the future with anyone I come across, I can get pretty deep at times and I've always been like this, even when I was 10 years old.

This is of course a very semantic debate but this video seems to be more focused on aspects of intelligence and how they build on each other rather than consciousness which is an awareness of oneself. This is prominent by the end of the video but it puts in a "thus must be explained by a need for food" frame. Which is intuitive but not necessarily proven. In fact much of our ability to rationalize isn't really that helpful to finding food. Instead the ability to be aware that you are thinking is most likely a vital prerequite to social animals and yet working backwards we can see the most primitive animals like bees are social. We are more than probably over estimating how advanced cognitive abilities have to be in order to be social. While there is a general track for "more food = more reproductive success" its certainly not a linear line. If that were true then trees are far more successful than humans. Instead a species quick adaptability to their environment in emergent ways means that no matter how stressed a species is it can continue to find niches.

As usual a really nice video but, as a filthy mind-body dualist, I think the info here slightly misses the core of the problem. Instead of addressing the question of the origin of consciousness, it addresses the question of the origin of biological awareness.

To see how these are different, you could program into a computer a game in which there are creatures like the worm, the chicken and the other examples given here, which have the same behavior when you start the simulation, and yet, due to them being just something in a computer, they aren't actually conscious in any way. These illusory computer NPC creatures would have biological awareness, as they would be able to detect other NPC creatures, and construct plans for how to survive, but they would lack their own subjective point of view, the kind that we humans have, where we can actually feel and experience things.

You could argue that these computer models would actually have a subjective point of view of their own and that they are actually conscious like humans are, but as they are just a logical mechanism programmed into a computer, you'd have to then prove why each of these logical mechanisms meets the requirements for having a subjective point of view, and so in the process you'd have to have a set of criteria for which to check each mechanism against. Now I'm not saying that this isn't possible, but this set of criteria is the core of the problem, it's not easy to come up with the set of criteria for which something must satisfy in order for it to be conscious.

We know human brains have something to do with a subjective point of view, the one we all have, but why is the physical human brain the right type of structure to connect to a conscious mind? Other parts of the body are also made of roughly the same ingredients, carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, silicon, and yet they are not conscious, or are they? Could a rock satisfy the set of criteria to be conscious? Does a consciousness even require a physical structure like a brain to exist, or can it exist absent a physical brain of any kind?

I might just be insane but I think it's worth thinking about this distinction, if nothing else it'll be food for thought hehe

Rocks have behavior. They melt with sufficient heat. They dissolve and evolve gas when heat and pressure conditions are right. They bond, fracture, crystalize, and undergo chemical change. We very reasonably attribute these behaviors to physical laws, however, to claim minerals are unchanging and therefore devoid of conscienceness is false. Perhaps the physical laws are the basis for a very simple and predictable consciousness. Perhaps consciousness is physical law and self-determination an emergent property of a sufficiently complex system. Perhaps rocks melt for the exact same reason that we flee from danger. What if atoms are radioactive for the same reason we have a favorite flavor of ice cream. What if the molecules of a freezing liquid huddle close together for the same reason we do when we get cold. What if the deterministic universe is just an illusion and everything is choice. What if the probabilities of quantum mechanics are no different than the probability you'll enjoy a movie or not. Of course from a scientific perspective that's all useless, unprovable at best, contrary to evidence at worst, but the next time you look out and you see a dead unthinking universe, a universe where there are no real meaningful consequences for the phenomena we observe, consider in fact that the opposite is true. consider that everything you see is important and that everything that happens really matters. it makes me very conscientious of the choices I make, of the behaviors I perform, and of the changes I make to the world. It also gives me some pleasure to imagine that those people I have loved and lost are not gone but rather have altered consciousness, have become diffuse and simplified. They've transformed and become unrecognizable, but they're not remote and they're not inconsequential to my life. It gives me a great sense of wonder to imagine that this individual consciousness is a temporary property of a more fundamental, universal, and enduring phenomena. A phenomenon that supersedes our perceived divisions, our judgments of each other, and our physical separation in space-time. A phenomena that does not just unite humanity, or living things, but in fact everything that we can observe and perhaps things we cannot. And while there's little to be gained in wondering if Pluto feels cold or if comets are afraid to fall toward the sun, the benefits of considering the impact our decisions can have and our membership in an unending community of conscious entities is well worth our consideration.

Be well, call someone you love, and remember that you and everything you do, matters.

TL DR; What if rocks were alive! That be crazy!

This video is entirely focused on one definition of consciousness: that awareness=consciousness. As they said, there's more than one idea out there, and that's just one of them, and that theory is just as disputed as all the others. For instance, we normally don't consider computers conscious even though they can in fact detect and respond to the outside world. Plants also can detect and respond to the outside world, but we normally don't count them as conscious either. The inherent problem with these discussions is that we have no way to detect consciousness. We can't even figure out if a human is conscious at any given moment, beyond them just later stating whether or not they were conscious.



The only real 'official answer' right now is that we haven't the faintest clue what conscious is and what is conscious and what is not. All we know is that humans are. And yes, its disputed as to whether or not animals are conscious.

All animals share a very similar brain that responds the same way to the same chemicals and neuro signals, we are part of the great ape family. All animals (including ourselves) have thoughts and feeling and in fact have the same emotions.

Anyone who has had a pet can do a simple demonstration. When your cat or dog come up to to be pet they are doing two things: 1. They are coming to you not your sofa, not the table, not anything else, they go to you. They have remembered that you pet them and when they want to be pet again they know to come to you. They are to distinguish between you and everything else. This demonstrates thought. 2. When your pet gets the pet they wanted they perform a response or pleasure, and when they get pet the wrong way they perform a response of discomfort. This demonstrates that they can feel. Using MRI scans we can see the areas of the brain light up where emotions are in the same areas of our brain when you account for size. The fact we can treat other animals that appear to show signs of mental illness using the same medication that we use to treat that mental illness shows they not just feel but also have emotions and the same ones.

Why can't we "listen" to what animals have to say when they communicate? Well, you can and you can't. All things communicate uses their senses, it what senses they use to communicate that can differ. When it comes to mammals the majority communicate using primarily visually and secondarily tactilely and tertiarily verbally. It is not to say that don't use their other senses to gather information, just they don't use those sense to express information. Perhaps you are thinking you have seen your dog sniff to gather information before. What they are doing if sniffing for pheromones, which humans do the same thing after shaking hands but this isn't the same thing as expressing information. It is not common to see a communication model not like the one mentioned previously in mammals but some mammals do, such as humans. Humans flip what most mammals do and communicate primarily verbally and secondarily visually and tactilely.

Your communication model is something  are born with and language is something you learn. Language is based on communication models, so all human languages you learn with primarily involve verbal components. Usually we don't involve visual communication in our language but rather use the same visual communication across our species and call this body language (which is a poor term as it isn't a language). There are some visual languages (such a sign language) but all of those languages are based upon the use of verbal language and directly translating that into hand singles or otherwise to express thought in the same way you do verbal language. Because some visual languages exist, we can and have taught other animals how to "speak" our visual languages, such as Koko the gorilla. We have a hard time learning other species visual languages because unlike ours they don't base their visual languages in a verbal like way.

Can other species that share the same communication models communicate with one another. Yes, but not completely. While latin isn't a communication model but rather a language we can latin demonstrate a point. There are languages called romance languages with are based upon latin: spanish, french, portuguese, italian, romanian, etc. While all of the romance languages are different languages, because they are based on the same language they can use those different languages to express thought amongst themselves without having to know the other language but have difficulty expressing increasing complex ideas. Different species that share the same communication model have developed their own languages based on the same model and can express ideas amongst each other but the more complex the idea the harder it is to express it. Just like we can express ideas in english to someone who only understands japanese by using on simple level, but when we share the same language we express even more complex ideas.

I feel like memory has got to be before sight in so far as which is more fundamental to consciousness. Blind people are obviously conscious. Helen Keller was obviously conscious. So the number of stimuli that goes into your brain/consciousness machine doesn't make you more or less conscious. But memory is necessary to construct an internal model of yourself and everything around you , as well to plan for future action (otherwise you're just starting from scratch every time something new happens). I think consciousness is really just that feedback loop of retaining memory about what is currently happening and applying it to some internal plan for the future.

In my opinion, you should've spent some time on clarifying what you mean by consciousness in this video, as it appears to be something different from "qualia" (the specific quality of properties of things in the world that we perceive), or conscious perception and experience. But those are probably what most people mean by consciousness. I don't see how qualia/cp/ce is necessary for all the things you describe in this video, as it seems unclear if and how these conscious percepts interact with the neural processing. Wouldn't the same neural processes lead to the same behavior if there was "nobody home" (i.e., in a zombie)? If so, is conscieous experience / qualia maybe a necessary byproduct of very complex information processing, and an inherent property of the universe? I know it's tempting to avoid these questions because nobody really has an answer for them, but what you describe seems to sidestep all of these questions by just describing ever more complex cognitive processes. While it seems plausible that consciousness exists on a spectrum as well, and reflects these increasingly complex cognitive processes, you really only describe the latter, not conscieousness itself.

Consider this mild criticism, I appreciate that it's an extremely difficult topic to cover.

Here’s a logical theory for you: What is the origin of consciousness? Well, if you think about it deeply, the most logical conclusion is that atoms make up its most basic units. Our brain cells allow for the generation of higher consciousness, but where does the consciousness in the brain cells come from? Atoms, or even subatomic particles, would be the logical conclusion. We actually have evidence for such particles being conscious. In the double slit experiment, the behavior of particles shot through one of two slits was determined by whether or not WE were observing it, on whether OUR consciousness was focused on it. Adding the concept of the oneness of universe seen in quantum physics with the idea that quantum strings connect every atom in the universe to every other atom, and the concept that the universe is a single conscious entity, the concept of the superconsciousness, starts to become more probable.

Video is heavily 'in vogue' with current trends in life sciences, promoting reductionism to objective physical reality from which the assumption follows that consciousness is an emergent property from the brain, i.e. the consciousness you experience as your own, private, internal movie/monologue is an "illusion" perpetrated upon you due to conspiration of your own biological parts after evolving over millions of years in the ongoing chemical chain reaction that is life as we know it from abiogenesis.

On the one hand the video distinguishes consciousness from intelligence, but with the other hand conflates cognitive processes with consciousness in an effort to derive it from basic physical life processes.

Another conclusion can be drawn from the focus on how cognitive processes developed from basic organisms and it should be given equal weighting in the video. As shown, the evolutionary environment selects the organisms that are capable of surviving (by finding food, etc.) just long enough to continue replication/reproducing, and these organism are not neccesarily the ones capable of best perceiving the correct, fundamental objective truth of physical reality. Furthermore, it is a very niche cognitive skillset, adaptable to only a thin slither of possible physical environments. This focus should therefore serve also to highlight the fallibility of the human mind and the possible limitations of scientific inquiry. Is it the brain which is perceiving the mind, or is it the mind which is perceiving the brain? It could very well be an incorrect assumption that consciousness is a physically emergent property and this should be addressed in the video as it is a line of enquiry not at odds with the scientific method albeit unpopular.

We know from evolutionary biology that multi-celled organisms evolved from single-celled organisms. It is unclear to what degree single-celled organisms gave up their autonomy to be able to act as a single organism and it is reasonable to suggest that our individual cells have maintained some degree of autonomy (consciousness) that we are totally unaware of.

A lot of human behavior is associated with subconscious processes in the prefrontal cortex that psycho-analysts refer to as the super-ego. This super-ego reflects the internalization of cultural rules in the form of memes. Such memes often influence human behavior in ways individuals barely realize and can be considered a form of collective consciousness.

A group of humans that is connected by means of memes can act as a single conscious organism, much like a cell of our body can act as a single conscious organism (= the way the cells of our body interact with their environment is the same as the way single cell organisms interact with their environment — and yes, the cells of our body can’t survive on their own… but neither can an individual bee or ant). This and many other factoids directly imply that consciousness is not so much a product of our brains but rather a product of complexity and connectivity.

From that perspective, the concept of consciousness can both be reduced to the molecular level and expanded to the universe as a whole, with the universe as a very complex holographic quantum computer.

That's a bit dishonest to characterize panpsychism as the view that the rocks have an inner life. You make it sound like we're arguing that they have thoughts and feelings. That is not and has never been our argument. Our idea is that they have a primitive level of consciousness that is below even that of a bacterium. There is a phenomenology to it, but it's very simple. There is a "what it's likeness" to being a rock and to experiencing the forces a rock can experience. But this state of consciousness is so low that it is not recognizable to complex creatures such as ourselves as having any phenomenology at all. As you create more complicated systems with more possible phenomoneological states, you get more complicated forms of consciousness. Ours happen to be the most complicated form that we know of.

The idea of panpsychism is that ALL things have phenomenology, but that our particular variety of phenomenology is an emergent sort created by all of these lower order types of expereince. A good analogy I like to use is the analogy of a piece of metal vs the atoms that make up that piece of metal. Both the piece of metal and the atoms that make it up can have different physical states, but the physical state of the piece of metal can affect the state of the atoms within and vice versa, and there are some states that only the piece of metal can experience which the individual atoms cannot. If I take the piece of metal and put it into the fire, the atoms within the metal do not experience heat. They experience an increase in kinetic energy. If I were describing the physical state of the atoms before and after the fire, I would simply say that their kinetic energy had been significantly increased. But what would i say of the metal? I would say that it is now in a state of being heated. If it is hot enough, I would say that it is glowing and giving off heat. I might even be able to say the metal is experiencing a state of being melted. or in the most extreme of cases, vaporized. But I would not be able to say this of the individual atoms, because they cannot experience heat or glowing, melting or vaporizing. They can only experience this increase in kinetic energy. That's it.

Humans are the same way. We, our minds, can experience a crazy amount of different things, from emotions to complex thoughts, to any number of physical sensations. But our cells do not. Our cells expereience only electro-chemical reactions. It is their interactions with each other that create our consciousness. Likewise, the molecules that make up the cells have experience too, but they only experience electromagnetic bonding and states of kinetic energy. And so, on, down the line, to the point where you have individual atoms whose experiences are even more limited.

"Words enable us to think about ourselves, and our place in the universe"... Hm. Do they? Of course they play a role in complex thought, but it is not uncommon for us to find ourselves in a situation were we cannot express our thoughts because they are too complicated. Or the thoughts we are having take so much longer to convey through words, but the pure thought, you can explain to yourself in less than a second, and you might get it in less than a second, but try conveying that deep, meaningful thought through words, and it just doesn't work.

This is why in my opinion the solution to both the discussion of the nature of consciousness and the question of the possibilty of artificial intelligences becoming conscious and self-aware.
As is described in this video, consciousness is something we gradually evolved. I'd further argue that it's not something we directly evolved, but a amalgamation of many behavioral patterns which in humans have become so complex that we are as conscious as we are, maybe just in different way, since their behaviour might also be different, but just as complex. (For example, dolphins behave differently from humans and live in totally different enviroments, but judging from their intelligent behaviour I'd infer that they are similarly conscious to us humans, just not in the completly same way.)
A similar thing can be said about creativity.
Therefore, other animals with a comparibale complexe behavior are also comparitably conscious. The more or less complex, the more or less conscious. And therefore artificial intelligences just need to reach a certain level of complexity to be obviously conscious. This would also suggest that other beings, whether they be biological or artifical, can also surpass humans in consiousness if they also surpass us in complexity. Perhaps even humans can augment themselves to be more complex and due to achieve a higher level of conciousness.
If we come back to the point of "different conciousnesses", maybe people of different talents and tendencies could also be describing to have different kinds of conciousness. For example, a more empathetic person is more complex in that regard and their brain might be more active in the area associated with empathy, so their consciousness, if we could visualize or describe it, would be different from a person who is less empathetic but who has a eidetic memory and whose brain is therefore more active and complex in the region associated with memory.
Though this is all conjecture and theory of course. :)

One that is firmly in the realm of science, for one.

Have you looked into the "subjective character of experience", or the "hard problem of consciousness", or "qualia", etc? That is the hard, philosophical problem. See e.g. David Chalmers, Thomas Nagel. In short, it's not particularly hard to envision how mental functions such as vision, memory, representation, self-awareness etc., may arise in nature, given how we're able to create objects with these qualities (self-driving cars for intance). What's hard to understand is how these functions acquire a subjective component. My smartphone can definitely see, interpret and memorize through its camera, processing and data storage capabilities; yet we wouldn't ascribe it consciousness in the sense that a dog or a human has. You cannot reduce this to human consciousness merely being more *complex*. Its complexity isn't really mysterious; its subjective character is.

I feel the video was being a bit too vague, but that's probably also because the vocabulary around consciousness is tricky, or let's say it's tricky to precisesly convery the nature of consciousness with words only.
It's true that consciousness is something we all experience, humans are special in that they can 'witness' themselves being conscious - we are selfaware.
You can ask yourself, "Am I?" and not matter what answer you give yourself, that right there is apparently the 'you' giving the response.
All other ways of 'witnessing', and in particular the world around us, require us to rely on our external senses, like eyesight, sense of gravity, hearing... (which are not necessary for a sense of consciousness, but important for survival)
The strange thing is that the only thing about our experience, the only thing we cannot 'experience together' is each others sense of "I am (in my head)" that response we can only get from ourselves. We can't look into other people's heads, but we naturally assume that they too have their own sense of being.
It's very very difficult to approach the topic due to how we ourselves, we humans not only have consciousness, but we are self-aware, and how we can draw our attention towards our own thinking.
We can come up with ideas, and concepts and symbols. We have language. We propose assumptions about the reality we perceive. And a lot of how we think about our experience of 'being' depends on the kinds of ideas and concepts that are fed to us when we are young, like by our parents. Our minds are convoluted consciousness indeed, it's very hard to reduce our understanding of what is required for consciousness down to the bare minimum, because we are already much more than 'just' consciousness. A difficult topic to find a starting ground for.

I think it would've been nice to talk more about the human consciousness first and sorting out a few misconceptions about consciousness instead of heading over to evolution right away. I also doubt that consciousness is in anyway required or beneficial really to 'finding food'. We could construct a high specialized robot that's programmed to gather resources as efficiently as possible to build more unites of its own kind and it wouldn't need consciousness of any sort to get the task done. Regardless, the true origin of conscousness is a very interesting topic, and it's sad that it's not talked about more since it directly refers to our very human nature.

Consciousness is the experience of feelings. It has nothing to do with behavior, which is what most of this video was about. The underlying assumption is that “if it behaves like a human, it must be conscious,” is an argument based off of intuition rather than logic. No amount of behavioral analysis will ever suggest or refute consciousness.
Also, the idea that consciousness was a gradual evolutionary development doesn’t make much sense. You either feel something or you don’t. It is strange to say that there was a “half-feeling” intermediate point along the path to developing consciousness. Is it possible to have “half” or “part” of a sensation? You might have cataracts, but you still have full awareness of blurred vision. Going blind also does not cause you to lose consciousness, because you are still fully present in experiencing smells, sensations, taste, and memories of sight.
I am also surprised there was no mention of whether artificial intelligence can be conscious.

Unfortunately, misleading title and poor understanding of what consciousness is. The video explains how, given that consciousness exists and supervenes on physical properties, consciousness became more complex. However, this is an issue that has never been a big question (since Darwin's formulation of evolution, anyway), and, in fact, can easily be answered in 10 minutes, as Kurzgesagt has demonstrated here.


What makes consciousness the biggest mystery of the universe, and what no one has yet answered with any success, is why consciousness exists in the first place and why it supervenes on physical properties (specifically, assuming epiphenomenalism, how something physical (our brain) can describe something mental (our conscious experience) so accurately if it is completely unaffected by it) - both of these have been assumed as a premise for this video.


Please rename the title to "the evolution of awareness of surroundings" and remove the claim that the evolution of external awareness (which you mistakenly call consciousness) a big, unanswered mystery (which you've clearly just solved that mystery yourselves).

I usually enjoy your videos very much, this is no exception. But unlike most videos I find myself disagreeing with your interpretation of consciousness. I agree with your initial definition of it but not with what follows.

I must say I derive much of what I believe from David Chalmers.

You seem to be equating complex behaviour with consciousness but there isn't much basis to believe this apart from the fact that we are conscious and have complex behaviour... However, correlation doesn't mean causation.

Consciousness really doesn't need complexity, although I understand the instinct to believe so. Consciousness is very simple as a concept. Is merely the subjective awareness on oneself. It doesn't need the input of the outside world given by senses. These senses, when they exist, just enhance the subjective inner world of a conscious being but they are not part of consciousness.

Imagine a computer running DOS on standby doing nothing. And image another running world of Warcraft. Both computers are running but the one running WOW has an enhanced "experience". Same goes with someone conscious only of himself, of his own mind or someone aware of the world around him given by its senses.

The world as perceived by the senses and interpreted by the brain is not Consciousness. It is a movie we all watch inside our heads. The subjective awareness or feeling of the observed IS consciousness.

Because if we take your interpretation for granted we have to seriously consider the possibility that my cleaning robot vacuum the house is conscious of himself. He exhibits behaviour, seeks litter, has sensors that make him "aware" of the world around it and has a purpose in life, which is vaccum the floor...

But is the robot really conscious?! I don't think so but then again, I may be wrong and you may be right...

I don't think there is such a thing as "free will". Hence I believe the behaviour of both computers and people follow mathematical and mechanistic rules. They aren't directly related to consciousness. I think Consciousness is merely the subjective experience of watching this "program" run, but doesn't or can't interfere with it.

Think of it like this: Consciousness is the ability to feel Vs reacting. The problem emerges from the fact the we have no idea where feeling comes from. Good luck trying to make a computer or a robot to "feel" anything, no matter how complex it is....

Something that always fascinated me is that since the most simple form of behaviour (If hungry --> Move, else --> don't move) is very mathematical, a logical extrapolation would be that more complex behaviors are also mathematical, but with a lot (lot) more parameters. This would mean that even our own behavior could theoretically be predicted if the function and enough parameters are known. This leads to the question, does free will actually exist, or is it just the result of a very complex math equation with many many parameters?



A question like that has no current answer, but my personal belief is that free will is an illusion and that our "choices" are simply deterministic actions taken based on past experiences, environment and other factors.

I'd posit that consciousness is an emergent property of multicellular physiology (and most likely neurophysiology).

To understand emergent properties, conduct a thought experiment with a single molecule of water. Document the properties of the molecule, then double your sample size. Keep repeating the doubling and documenting. At some point you'll start to see patterns emerge, as a collection of molecules can be in a solid/liquid/has state - a property that emerges because there is a sufficient quantity.

Consciousness is like that. We don't see it in simple constructions because you need a sufficient quantity of cells working in tandem (and of the right type) for the trait to emerge. It is also difficult to identify the source of the property because most science is reductionist and cuts up observed sample to a size that doesn't have the property. In other words, consciousness is a trait of a sufficiently complex system and not some atomically identifiable component (based on the best scientific evidence to date).

In the end the question "what is the self" is one of those fascinating questions that has been contemplated in many domains if religion, philosophy, and science and there is no definitive answer. However, there is a great deal of evidence and we can use it to make some "best explanations to date based on observations" (such as there has been no evidence of a life force or spirit, so non-physiological explanations are not the best explanations to date - find a measurable spirit/soul energy organ and then the best explanation will change... but not before).

Interesting video, but it is somewhat unintentionally misleading to insinuate that most of the organisms mentioned in this video have conscious awareness.


We don't know if Western Scrub Jays, for example, are truly "aware" that there are other organisms just like them that have their own perception of the world. It is entirely possible that natural selection simply favored the jays that hid their food from competitors, and that this trait was genetically passed on through generations. We DO NOT know if organisms like the Western Scrub Jays are actually aware of their relation to others.

It'd say "consciousness" (sentience), beyond the ability to perceive the world, is foremost the ability to develop a "self", which inevitably has "memory" as a requirement. Therefore, "memory" seems to be where the line can be drawn between entities merely driven through chemistry vs. entities with actual sentience. That's why a housefly is sentient but not a random amoeba. However, that line of thinking also means even some current predictive and prescriptive AI fall under our definition of sentience, which is weird. Luckily there's a further step beyond sentience : sapience. Wisdom. An ability to care about oneself and others that our housefly and AI both lack for now.

I have to say I was actually somewhat convinced by a panpsychicist, though not on his terms, and maybe not with panpsychicism. He shrouded things in sort of bullshit mystical-sounding vagueties, but I thought about it and I think it makes sense, though it's not related to whole objects like rocks. It's more that the rock, the air around it, our dead skin cells, and pretty much everything is alive with microcosms of conscious activity. But hear me out. It's not that they perceive anything at all, certainly not to any metacognitive extent. It's that they contain the same parts as conscious beings. So say we define consciousness along a spectrum with quantized values. Humans are 1.00 unit of consciousness. The bosonic matter making up the universe (maybe even other fundamental particles) on their own would be like... 1x10^-10000000000000 units of consciousness each. Where the guy lost me is where he sort of almost implied that these microcosms of consciousness would explain macroscopic consciousness, which has obvious flaws, like that if that were the case, extremely massive consciousnesses would arise out of things that are made up of a bunch of particles. Like if you just have one thing that is solidly comprised of 1x10^10000000000000 of those 1x10^-10000000000000 conscious unit masses then what he said to me doesn't account for that that would essentially make a human. Anything as large as a human could be as conscious as one.


Obviously, consciousness is an emergent property of different organic systems. (organic in the sense that there are specialized organs, I'm not discounting conscious AI) But here's where I justify it. As far as we know, our brains are full of systems that interpret electrical signals. Bosonic matter reacting chemically in response to electrical stimuli and rearranging things and storing things kind of like a computer. So if you stripped the brain down to one bit--on or off--that would still be one fragment of a brain. One fragment of consciousness. The universe is buzzing with electrical impulses bumping bosonic matter around. Is the consciousness the flow of electrons, or the interactions with bosonic matter? Does it really matter what kind of particle they are, a la string theory? Does interaction with anything at all comprise one fragment of consciousness, as it has the potential to be interpreted by a hypothetical organic system from which a consciousness could arise? I think it makes sense. You could say that one single bit is a fragment of a computer, in fact I think it would be disingenuous to claim otherwise, as a computer is just an emergent property of an organic system that interprets information, and it doesn't need to be whether an electrical bit is on or off, but could be extended to qbits or even levers and punch cards. The universe is full of single bits, is what I'm saying. Every unchecked wild interaction that comprises literally everything is one fragment of consciousness. There's nothing to process that consciousness, but it is an "experience" awaiting interpretation from a system. So a lightning strike is like a torrent of bits that hasn't been interpreted by anything. Everything is a signal, and signals are what comprise consciousnesses.


The rock isn't conscious at all to the standards humans use, but the universe doesn't have to behave according to human intuition. The fact that it is comprised of information means that it is interpreting the information around it. It's dark, it feels nothing, it doesn't know what darkness or nothing is, and yet it perceives something with each change in state, reacting accordingly, and if you arrange enough of those interactions in a fancy enough way they become instincts and eventually thoughts. With infinite lightning strikes you'd eventually get a stream of data that is identical to a person thinking about what to have for breakfast, but on the way there you'd have near-infinitely many permutations of someone thinking about what to have for breakfast and a gradient of complexity leading up to that. So though I ascribe to a strictly materialistic non-metaphysical philosophy, I don't think it's incompatible with panpsychicism, or whatever thing I just described is.

This is interesting, but completely wrong. Consciousness isn't necessary for any of the capabilities described in this video.

A computer can be programmed to respond to sensory input (e.g. sight, smell), interpret that input to identify objects and make spacial calculations of where they are, store the information of where they were last seen, predict where they will go, make time-based calculations, and much, much more. Yet the same computer that does these things gives no more indication of being conscious (i.e. self-aware) than a rock.

Creatures could have gained these capabilities without gaining consciousness.

Come to think of it, we do exactly the same things with artificial intelligence right now. It started off as random impulses for a toy car for example, which would drive around until it hit a wall, and would then turn around and drive on. We then started to give the machines instructions on how to behave best, arming them with cameras and sensors to be aware of their surroundings - and now we have self-driving cars that react upon given impulses accordingly. The next, and last, step to human-like consciousness is self awareness and the ability to question one's existence. The question is, if we will ever be able to create such a thing without understanding it ourselves. Maybe it will create itself first.

This still doesn't explain where phenomenal experience comes from. When an AI sees things via camera, it doesn't actually see the image the way we do but reads the code converted from the camera input. In other words, AI mimics sight, but doesn't actually see in the fundamental way living creatures like us do.

So if AI and the human consciousness are functionally identical, as neuroscientists argue, why doesn't AI have phenomenal experience - or more pertinently, why do we living things have phenomenal experiences while functionally identical AI doesn't? We don't need to phenomenally experience the universe to survive and thrive as biological organisms, but we do. So why?

Potential issues I see with the video:
1.) At 3:01 and 3:55 they use decision trees / algorithms to describe what's going on. While there's nothing wrong with that, I think it implicitly drags in assumptions about the computational model of consciousness that don't get critically examined enough. Nowadays people are obsessed with computers (and AI) because, after all, they are the most important and revolutionary new force in our world, but that can sometimes bleed over into how we think about the mind and consciousness. I think this way of thinking is pernicious. We can't seriously answer the question of whether computers are conscious if our starting point is a theory of consciousness inspired by computers.
2.) I can't really be mad at panpsychism being dismissed (even though I have a soft spot for it), but I don't think bringing in behavior is a good argument to pull. A brain in a vat may be conscious but not show obvious behaviors to clue us in to that. You can have a complete description of something's behavior (say, my stomach rumbling, neurons firing, my feet moving my body to the fridge) without saying whether or not it is conscious (what thoughts I had, how hunger feels qualitatively). Behaviorism is nice because it lends itself to scientific analysis, but it's under a lot of fire from philosophers.
3.) It looks to me like there's some blurring between consciousness and intelligence: are delayed gratification and theory of mind really questions of consciousness? I'm not sure. I'm really forward to the next videos because it sounds like they'll clear up their stance on that.
4.) Relatedly, in the example of theory of mind we may be (ironically) projecting that conscious ability to imagine others' perspectives onto animals. One animal may see another and feel generally unnerved and want to move its food without thinking about the other animal's desires or imagining what it is like to be that other animal. This is a super minor point in the video because it's just an illustration

Obviously you can't answer everything in these short videos and they did a stunning job introducing the topic and representing the ideas. It's awesome how few problems they left open.

For anyone interested in diving deeper on these topics I recommend:
Thomas Nagel on why explaining consciousness is so hard to explain even in typical evolutionary terms.
David Chalmers on why panpsychism isn't as dumb as you might think.
Heidegger or Dreyfus if you want to learn about embodied cognition.

When you say that you need vision to visualise the world around you in order to plan: Are you saying that blind people are not conscious?

That Trichoplax Adhaerens that slows down in the presence of food must be aware of the food being present. It doesn't plan – it doesn't need to: A random walk is more effective. It doesn't change its behaviour beyond direction and speed – and it doesn't reflect on it either: Changing its behaviour more fundamentally has no benefit.
And yet it experiences the difference between food and no food being present. If that isn't enough to give rise to qualia from the realm of consciousness, then I have to question if humans are conscious at all.
(Because humans do change their behaviour (at least until puberty), but are equally unable to change the way in which they do so.)

The Dugesia Tigrina has quite paradoxical behaviour: It only expends energy when it is running low on energy, and conserves energy when it has a lot of it. Except that digestion may also consume energy, and so that description is at best misleading, and probably wrong altogether.

At what point does changing one's behaviour in reaction to a changed state (in the environment or in the body, which to a nervous system is also part the environment) cross the threshold to being reflection?
Plants change their behaviour depending on a big number of factors, sometimes drastically. Yet even in the context of single-celled organisms, I only ever see animal eukaryotes used as examples.

Quite a good video, the only issue here is that evolution is not forward looking and linguistic development of the kind that you touch on at the end requires more than simple communication of intent (which can be accomplished by proto-languages present in non-human animals). Rather, it needs relational thought and reasoning. We used to think relational reasoning  was a purely human phenomenon since every non-human animal couldn't do it (relational match to sample task can't be solved in general by non-human primates). However, recent studies into certain corvid sub-species seem to suggest they have relational capacity which opens a whole new avenue for study since if they actually do, it would be a case of convergent evolution between us and them given that our common ancestor certainly didn't have any relational reasoning capabilities. Either way, relational reasoning seems to be a non-continuous process (you can't get half-way to relational reasoning, it's an all or nothing deal) which makes explaining why we have it by typical evolutionary models of trait development a little tricky. As far as I know there are a few papers suggesting that it took a large enough pre-frontal cortex for it to just start happening, and the incrementally larger pre-frontal cortex allowed for more evolutionary fitness which would explain it nicely. However, there are plenty more papers (which I happen to find more compelling) that suggest there really is a fundamental difference in the type of neural computation needed for relational vs featural cognition. (see: Penn, Derek C., Keith J. Holyoak, and Daniel J. Povinelli. "Darwin's mistake: Explaining the discontinuity between human and nonhuman minds." Behavioral and Brain Sciences 31.2 (2008): 109-130.)

I recently got pet praying mantises and have been studying them a lot. i'm surprised they aren't used in psychological testing, more, if ever. This video focuses on a lot of the so-called "easy problems" (why organisms react to stimuli, control their behavior, and have memory), which is fine, but it leaves out a large part of the equation. Why is there a subjective experience to life at all? How do we know that there is something it is like to be a chicken but there isn't anything it is like to be trichoplax adhaerens? Why do physical processes give rise to an inner life in organisms, and how complex do physical processes need to be to form an inner life?

Hopefully this idea is being saved for a future video, but it may be too abstract for this channel. I think any conversation about the origins of consciousness should at least mention the hard problem, since it's such a huge part of the current philosophy.

Tbh, I quite disagree with the statement that consciousness =/= intelligence. Quite the opposite actually, I'd go so far as to say you can directly define intelligence via conscious reflection of your own deeds.
Not only is consciousness what differentiates us from less evolved and less intelligent species, I find humans that are the most intelligent are usually very "aware that they are".
What I mean by that is the awareness of your existence. I have yet to meet someone I'd consider smart who is not "aware" of his existence (Ofc this is merely subjective experience so no real scientific method but how would you even measure that?). It sounds really stupidly simple but so many people exist without being aware that they do.
The basic principle "cogito ergo sum", "I think therefore I am", is something I'd even take a step further to "percipio ergo sum", "I perceive, therefore I am".
I think the ability to reflect yourself as a human in spacetime, think about your own existence and your own doing from an outside perspective is a feat that requires extraordinary amounts of intelligence. Unfortunately not everybody is able or even willing to try, those are generally people that I find to be less intelligent.

Self reflection is, imo, the ONLY way to define TRUE intelligence because it combines the ability to realize your own perspective with your ability to think outside the box and view your actions as a bystander. But then again, how do you define intelligence? You just "know" certain people are dumber than others but what exactly are you measuring here? Going by this very unscientific definition of actual ability of self reflection I'd go so far as to say that consciousness defines intelligence.

Good video as always and great montage. My p.o.v if I may is that, both intuitively and more in depth, to attribute consciousness to purely random stochastic statistical processes both in the macro and the micro is far from satisfying both intellectually and scientifically. Things can be stochastic and statistical (i.e. random), necessary (not in the metaphyisical sense but in the scientific sense of deriving necessarily from previous states of affairs) or designed (yep, that option does exist). As for consciousness, we see a clear intelligible logic behind it (duh) which brings it into being, and not a purely stochastic process. There is a process that systematically brings out consciousness (nowadays via reproduction for ex.). As for necessity or design, even if we presuppose that consciousness necessitates from the laws of physics, these are far from being necessary and could have been different, even in a multiverse scenario. Hence, for me design is what makes most sense. Can't wait for the next videos. Peace out! ;)

To be honest I'm not so sure about this. Can't all this be explained by a an extremely complex yet physically understandable chain reaction of different physical body parts and cells interacting with each other in each organism, like a row of dominoes? To me that isn't consciousness. I see consciousness as the (perhaps magical) thing that makes each of such a chain reactions feel like it's a separate entity, existing.

I can feel what's going on with my chain reaction, I'm kinda hungry. But I cannot feel what's going on in somebody else's chain reaction. The fact that 1. I can feel that, and 2. I can't feel what another chain reaction is, is where consciousness lies. It is both the "being", and the separation between organisms that feel the same "being". At least that's the way it seems to me. It is very hard to articulate this, and I can't (at least not yet) conceive the possibility of a scientific explanation for this fact.

Great video! But I think we need to generalise this idea. It is fair to think that 'food' was the first thought that lead to consciousness, but I think it can be more general, like 'survival'. Then we can extend this ideas to non living, per se, as well. A rock does not move to get food, but it needs to be rigid and tough to survive, which it is. Atoms combine, re-combine to survive (probably), when they combine in a certain way, they don't need food to survive, but when in a different way, they do and hence consciousness emerges. I also think there is an element of the time dimension here, a rock when not moved still weathers, which is ageing in terms of biological forms, that means the rock did move in the dimension just very very slowly. We can say that a parasite moves faster in the time dimension, but both the rock and the parasite show movement in the time dimension.

The problem is that, in order to explain consciousness this way, you need to equivocate. 'Consciousness' means two things: (1) that everything we sense, perceive, and know, is experienced through phenomena -- our first-person perspective, in other words, and (2) the reactive behavior of animals to their environment (these are inexact definitions). Through most of this video, you're clearly using the second meaning, but this is a cheat. No one thinks that it's impossible to explain how creatures can react to their environments, or to make machines that can do the same.

You mention panpsychism, in this video. You'll find that, not only is panpsychism unfalsifiable (it's a philosophical theory, not a scientific one, so this isn't a problem, per se), but that, using the definition of 'consciousness' implicit in this video, you couldn't begin to explain what it would even mean for a rock, or a subatomic particle to be conscious.

The two definitions of consciousness are often confused, because (as far as I know) they are coextensive, and because we only infer the consciousness (in the first sense) of others from their consciousness (in the second sense).

The difficulty in explaining consciousness (in the first sense) is not because it's so complex, but because it's so simple, and so unlike everything else in experience. When we are aware of something, there is a way in which we are also aware of our awareness, itself. And this awareness is, to us, irreducible. If we examine anything, even ourselves, from a third-person perspective, that thing can be, at most, correlated to our conscious experience. The two can never really be identified with one another because our consciousness is defined, primarily, by our first-person perspective.

Consciousness is merely the result of a working brain. There's nothing mysterious about it. Chop off your head, damage your brain, or even just imbibe some alcohol into the blood stream of the brain and your consciousness - your ability to think, react, experience - is changed or impaired. It's an impressive program running on some complex wetware, but it's nothing more than that.

First,  you were almost confusing consciousness with mere perception. Consciousness involves awareness of yourself and can get to awarness of mere awarness at the most mysterious case. Then you set up a ladder of consciousness that depend on perception factors and intelligence. You claim they're not the same but you rely on it to give your new measurable view of consciousness. Being able to identify food and select it and avoid predators while being aware of your hunger/digestion state IS NOT a sign of deep consciousness. If you claim so, then a machine I can program my own to do all of these is conscious.

Consciousness is not sense, it's not memory, it's not intelligence nor inner representations. Consciousness is not a vague concept, it's an unexplainable one. You cannot translate it to language.

If you cannot translate it or express it to others, you cannot share an analysis about it either.

Think of color : you can talk about the wavelength of photons and you can talk about energy levels. You can tell people that you have a representation of colours. But can you tell someone what it means to get in your shoes and see your red and not just red? Can you express or share your inner perception? An external analysis can only know whether you saw red or blue or whatever. It cannot tell what you properly experienced. You cannot know if my green is your red.

Consciousness, similarly, is unexplainable and unexpressable by nature. This video only attempts to falsely portray it in a vague sea of different unrelated meanings such as perception, intelligence,  goal making ... , ironically trying to render you unconscious of what consciousness is, and what specifically your consciousness is.

Consciousness is, I guess, one of the most confusing subjects for many people, so I wondered what your approach would be. Of course it's hard to expect complex explanations to be given in 10 minutes of video, but you unfortunately lacked to touch the most crucial part of it, which are qualia. Many people also seem to have hard time getting that concept, even though - I believe - they all experience them. Qualia are the qualitative features of all our experiences - the redness of red, the pain in the pain, in other words, something that makes experience "like something", rather than just a blank and dry piece of information. Your description would rather fit a video called "How our motor and cognitive systems might have evolved", than the subject of concsiousness. You were somewhere near the topic when you mentioned panpsychism, not that I believe it's true, but at least it's on the subject and a valid point in discussing this phenomena. Having even very accurate and adaptive sensory and analytic capabilities is something that is in no way enough to talk about consciousness - think about our smarphones and apps in them that can, say, recognize your face. Does the telephone actually see you? Some would argue that surely this is not impossible, but we surely can imagine that it does not, which makes it an uncosciuous automaton. So, gathering information and reacting to them in an adaptive manner DOES NOT equal consciousness and is entirely off topic. It could be used as an explanation of evolutionary processes that led to emergence of consciousness, but in fact they are basically different topics and certainly are not the essence of the question here.

For all of you intrigued by this subject I strogly recommend reading books by Daniel Dennett, David Chalmers or John Searle.

Well, I would say this depends how you define consciousness. Indian/eastern philosophy helps in this.

For a start, why don’t you think atom has consciousness? Why don’t you think subatomic particles has consciousness? If string theory is proven correct, why don’t you think the strings have consciousness? You could narrow this down to infinitely small (and infinitely large amounts to encompass the universe).

So then, what this video implies as consciousness, isn’t it really just brain action? Thoughts and action by the brain and nervous system in response to external stimuli, rather than consciousness itself? Just that the brain gets more and more complex through evolution. But why do you refer to the brain’s thoughts and responses as consciousness, leaving out the individual components (like cells) that make up the brain, and the body. Sometimes, we respond without brain action at all, like non-autonomous neural response (e.g. knee-jerk reaction, response to fire). These responses are hard wired into the genetics and tissue make-up of the body. This happens by neural response without the brain’s involvement. Is that consciousness then?

But never mind me, this is still more with the semantics really. Difference in the defining things. Looking forward to future videos on this. 😁

I aprecciate this video. But it deals with a mechanistic view of consciousness.
Experience, or consciousness, does not seem to be an evolutionary asset, and that's a big problem, that explanations like this inevitably walk around. Our brains COULD evolve to produce EXACTLY the same responses to external stimuli through electrochemical processes, without the conscious part of us.

And this explanation doesn't really tell us why consciousness lies in the specific cognitive areas that it does, and not in the millions of other unconscious processes of the brain, which seem to be the same in physical nature (both are neural electrochemical signals).
To understand this point here's an example. Just take conscious and unconscious, and flip them around. Seeking food could be an unconscious process, and metabolizing it, could be a conscious one. Why are we conscious of some of our behavioral traits rather than all?

And then there's another problem, why does our consciousness have the nature that it has? An easy way to wrap your head around this would be to ask a question like this. Why is red red? It could be blue. Our consciousness only needs to be internally consistent most of the time. If someone took the experience of blue and replaced it with that of red, in evolution there would be no difference in behavior. We would recognise that blood is blue, just call it red, and that the sky is red and just call it blue. Consciousness cannot be fully explained just in the context of serving us biologically, because it doesn't do that. It seems to be an emergent property of our brains function, but nevertheless, different in nature. This whole situation has vast implications on free will, philosophy of mind, the nature of existence etc.

Entertain the idea of a metaphysical view of consciousness, in a way that wouldn't fit in the physicality of the mechanistic point of view because it simply doesn't seem to fully belong there.

If you delve deep enough into certain mind-states (e.g. via psychedelics, deep meditation, sensory deprivation, etc) you realize that everything is conscious, and consciousness is everywhere all the time, and has always existed. It can inhabit physical matter, BUT it precedes physical matter ontologically, and will still be around after the physical matter is gone. It exists outside of matter, time and space. I know the mainstream materialist-reductionist mindset will reflexively dismiss this as un-scientific hokum. To them, I quote The Bard: “There are more things in heaven and earth, Horatio, than are dreamt of in your philosophy.” A person can do all the peer-reviewed neurological experiments and brain scans they want, but until they actually dive in the "deep end" themselves and confront consciousness in the immediacy of visceral, firsthand experience, they're only seeing a tiny sliver of a MUCH larger picture (indeed a picture so large that we don't even know what its limits are, if any).
