In his science-fiction novels “Blindsight” and “Echopraxia”, marine biologist Peter Watts entertains the idea that human consciousness might be a mal-adaptive side-effect of complex cognition, an emergent biological phenomenon, a thesis he later labelled a spandrel interpretation of consciousness. He even goes as far as describing consciousness as parasitic, referring to an experiment that showed conscious decision-making to lead to worse results than unconscious decision-making. When asked on an internet forum about how he came up with this punchline he responded that he tried thinking of a reason for why an intelligent agent would need consciousness and failed to come up with a satisfying answer.

As he stated at the Popular Science Forum Ratio 2017, the problem with discussing consciousness to begin with is, that natural sciences do not provide a mechanism for how changes in electric charges should result in subjective experience. We all assume to share this form of subjective experience but have no objective way of confirming this assumption.

Consciousness does not mean self-awareness, but subjective experience. Self-awareness refers more to an organism's understanding of the self in the social and environmental context. Subjective experience on the other hand does not require an organism to have a understanding of the self, but simply describes that “something feels something”. I believe that the two get confused easily, because (especially social) self-awareness is a state that dominates human consciousness.

Intuitively, one might expect consciousness to be related to intelligence, since solving complex problems usually requires conscious focus (intentional attention). However, as mentioned above, evidence might point to the contrary: Not only do we tackle complex problems without consciously computing all parts of the problem. But more surprisingly, in his work on the deliberation-without-attention effect Dijksterhuis uncovers that unconscious decision-making can even lead to to objectively superior choices than conscious decision-making.
There are various theories on how consciousness arises. Some think it is resulting from the mysterious workings of quantum mechanics, mostly because both, consciousness and quantum mechanics seem to be confusing. Some argue that natural sciences as we know them will have to be altered to be able to explain consciousness.
A theory more grounded in the biology of cognition is that consciousness emerges from the integration of various motor commands into action. An example for this could be a person jumping out of a plane with a parachute. Humans naturally refrain from falling from great heights, a tendency we all witness when looking down a with steep cliff. The sky-diver has to integrate the repelling effect of altitude and the wish to jump to actually act, resulting in the conscious experience when going through the process of decision-making.

If consciousness has not evolved as adaptive trait but it is simply a natural phenomena that it feels like something to be a complex system, this might have far reaching implications on how we formulate our ethics, not just in regard to how we treat other animals or even plants, but also for the future of artificial intelligent networks. (wrote this for Uni a few month ago)

This was an extremely disappointing video. I usually love Kurzgesagt's videos, but this one did not even address the question it poses in its title, or in the beginning of the video. Instead of explaining the schools of thought around the existence of consciousness, they spend the entire video explaining the content of consciousness and how this content has become more complicated over time. The question of consciousness, though integrally connected to its content, is not the same question as where the content of consciousness came from.

Not only did the writers completely disregard the original premise in this episode, they took a decidedly modern and Western view of the entire question of consciousness. They posed the universe as a dead and inannimate place where somehow something (consciousness) arose out of nothing.

This argument is nonsensical in that nothing can arise from nothing. Everything is given rise to by previous causes and conditions. Thus, even if the contents of consciousness can become more complex over time based on the evolution of mind, the existence itself of consciousness (what the video claims to address, but does not) remains untouched.

A legitimate theory to explain the existence of consciousness is panpsychism, but the authors choose to subtly discredit this school of thought by representing it with a hokey animation of a being floating in space with a magical glowing rock. They also discredit it by throwing it away on the shakey ground that we have no evidence for the existence of the inner world of something like a rock/mineral. Reality check: you have no real evidence for the existence of an inner world other than your own. Period. The existence or nonexistence of others is a belief structure, and the only consciousness you can prove for certain is your own. The author's argument for the discrediting of panpsychism is the exact argument you could use to discredit the very existence of all other conscious beings. In addition, disproving the inner life of objects like minerals, but edifying your own inner life makes no sense - you are nothing other than a complicated arrangement of mineral and water.

Finally, I want to add that this video completely disregards Eastern schools of thought on this matter - rigorous and logically based systems of thought which have been developed for thousands of years compared to the West's several hundred. This video presents a very lopsided view of the human exploration into our own nature. It takes one of the greatest mysteries we face and, instead of sharing and opening to the mystery, collapses it into a mechanical, evolutionary process in a dead/unintelligent universe.

If this is a topic you are interested in, do not stop with this video. Explore your awareness with curiosity, and stay open.

I disagree about the justification of the assumption that consciousness is probably derived from evolution. Hume’s problem of induction kills this assumption. It is made worse as we only have a single element to induce off of.

Under normal induction, one can notice that the last thousand ravens were black, and reasonably concluded that ravens everywhere are black. This requires the existence of at least one other raven to start making this assumption justifiable. A single raven cannot be justified as a representative of the group (consider trying to make assumptions about all universes using only our own).


For each person, we are only aware of our own consciences. We can reasonably guess that other humans have consciousness (as we are human), but as to whether or not anything else is conscious, we can only speculate. After all, it is entirely possible that you are the only conscious thing in existence. You might be an experimentee in a deeply complex simulation where you have been given amnesia to make the simulated experience more convincing. Or you could just be a real freak of nature that you have an inner world, and everyone else is a ‘philosophical zombie’ (a person who acts exactly like someone with an inner world, but lacks one; imagine a very intelligent computer that can pass a Turing test, but is not conscious).
Little did us know, but we're actually a particular rock's descendant...

I'm disappointed in this video's lack of philosophical depth. There is no mention at all of the very profound "hard problem of consciousness," which is the question of how it is that physical causes can translate to inner subjective experience at all--or, as the subtitle states, "how unaware things become aware."  Kurzgesagt starts off with the philosophical assumption that consciousness is a byproduct of material complexity (nervous systems). Yet, there is contention in philosophy about whether this is a proper categorization. A strong case can be made, for example, for idealism, the point of view that consciousness is actually the only true substance of reality--that it is fundamental and irreducible (see "Why Materialism is Baloney," by Bernardo Kastrup). Max Planck, the founder of quantum theory, said, "I regard consciousness as fundamental. I regard matter as derivative from consciousness. We cannot get behind consciousness. Everything that we talk about, everything that we regard as existing, postulates consciousness." The point is, there is so much more to the mystery of consciousness than its apparent survival utility. It is a central consideration in metaphysics, and in my opinion its ontological status is the deepest rational inquiry possible, yet this video does not give due appreciation to the true depth of the problem--instead opting to start with a metaphysical presupposition without explaining or defending it. I'm disappointed only because the kinds of things I mention here are actually more captivating than the mere evolutionary path of conscious complexity, and if visited in typical Kurzgesagt style, would have, I think, made for a more interesting video.

Here's what I think consciousness is - it's a complex and deterministic reaction engine. Think of a see-saw, you push one end down and the other end comes up - this is the simplest form of a reaction engine, 1 input gives you exactly 1 output.


This is likely how the earliest forms of life worked, with a simple one input and one output (eg. hungry > eat). Over time, life would have evolved to take more than one input and produce a corresponding output - it's still a 1-to-1 mapping but there's just more of it (eg. hungry > eat; dark > hunt; bright > hide). Then the next stage would be to combine inputs and/or outputs. This would be the most basic version of consciousness but it's still very obviously deterministic (eg. hungry + dark > hunt; hungry + bright > wait).


The secret sauce comes with the ability to take an actual sensory input and combine it with a self-generated input from memory and then produce a new output - an output that may have been different had there been only sensory input. Now we have something special - though it's still a simple input-produces-output situation, we have an invisible input coming from stored knowledge, and there can be a great deal of variance here. Then as the output is initiated - we also observe the effectiveness of the output and record that into memory also, so the next time this situation arises again, the invisible input from memory gets even more unique.


The whole thing is still deterministic but over time you are able to combine simple sensory inputs with such a mind-blowing amount of varied stored knowledge input that the output always seems like a conscious choice that's special every time we encounter a similar situation. Ultimately though I believe that we are still very deterministic - it's just that our lifetime of memories experiences are so vast, some of which we aren't even aware of that we know that it seems like we're actually making a choice and that we could have gone either way, but I think that it's an illusion - because the choice is already determined based on the person's collected knowledge of the universe surrounding them and the sensory input they are getting at that time, but the deterministic nature of it is too complex because there's too many variables that leads to the choice that we think it's special.


Going back to the see-saw analogy, now the see-saw has evolved from a single see-saw to billions of interconnected see-saws that take thousands of inputs and produce an output that seems special - but it's not, because the output is still decided by the combination of inputs and how the see-saws are interconnected. We just don't realise it because there are too many inputs and the interconnection of the see-saws are very unique based on our life experiences.

Kinda reminds me of a peculiar question I came up with for a story.


In that story, nano-machines that can replace cells in the human brain and that function near identical to real ones exists.


So the question goes that if you where to use them to create a perfect replica of someone's brain, then the replica would be someone else in your eyes, right? They are identical, but still different.


But what if we took, slowly over time, and replaced each brain cell by one of those nano-machines, one by one? Replacing one doesn't do anything significant, right? But then, at which point would you say someone is different? Or do they remain the same? When all of their brain has been replaced? Half? Do their consciousness become replaced or do they keep it all the way through?


And to add to this conundrum, the one going through this can't answer since the original consciousness will disappear if they do, while the new one can't answer either since for that ones perspective, nothing has changed.


Not sure this makes sense to others, but it is a sort of question I kinda ponder for various sci-fi and cyberpunk works.

I absolutely love Jordan Peterson's theory (which he admits is pretty crazy) that consciousness evolved as a result of the stimulation of the prefrontal cortexes of primitive females during attacks by predators. As women in a primitive setting were mostly powerless to defend themselves against dangerous predators and were responsible for nurturing and defending their young, all they could do is look on in terror hoping that the warriors could fend off the threat. While this is going on, the fear and anxiety is stimulating their prefrontal cortex causing it to grow, and bigger prefrontal cortex obviously would've been something naturally selected for. This happened so much over time that we started to realize that predators weren't something that either did or didn't exist, but rather that a predator is something that can happen now OR in the future. By realizing that threats were something that could happen in the future, we simultaneously grasped the concept of the future, and what our consciousness is heavily based on is the place that we are at the time that we're there. We're spatial-temporal beings, because if we weren't, we never would've found out that danger is something that could happen at any time in any place. His evidence for it was even more fascinating - the oral traditions that go back tens of thousands of years (if not more), particularly the Adam & Eve story which is theorized to be an oral tradition at least 20,000 years old.


Eve gains complex intelligence of the world (consciousness) by eating fruit from the tree of life after being tempted by a snake (predator), and then gives it to Adam (gives birth to men that carry this trait) and the first thing they both realize is that they're naked (they're vulnerable at all times and can be easily killed). God tells them they must leave the paradise of Eden (the blissful ignorance of not being aware of one's mortality) and that as a result, Adam will have to work for the rest of his life (to ward off future harm and prepare for threats) and that Eve would be cursed with terrible pain in childbirth (as a result of the vastly larger brains that human beings now have).

Great video, but I think you should be careful in making the claim that non-human animals have a theory of mind, or the ability to represent the mental states of others. As far as we know, only humans have this capability, and we don't develop it until 5-7 years of age.

You mentioned the scrub jays hiding their food as a result of their understanding that other jays have the same goals as them. That is a big stretch, and one which is not supported by evidence in the animal behavior literature. A more likely explanation is that they have a "theory of behavior" which allows them to act based on the observed actions of their conspecifics. In other words, if they see a bird steal their food, then they will be more vigilant in hiding it away from other birds in the future. Importantly, this doesn't require that they can reason about the mental states of those birds.

- is consciousness a s specific ability or a aggregation of multiple capabilities?
- is consciousness an objective thing that can be measured or a subjective thing akin to beauty that cannot have any strict amount and/or definition?
- do humans still have consciousness when they are asleep/drunk?
- what does a computer program have to do in order for us to call it conscious?

Eyes, ears, and many more things couldn't evolve. Evolution assumes small incremental (small, slow process) steps. It needs small incremental steps otherwise the chances of evolution happening get more and more bizzare. When scientists say evolution they mean genetic mutations guided by natural selection to get species better and better fit for survival. Let's use the eye as an example. Some genetic mutations give you half of 0.3% of one eye. Natural selection would need this to benefit you to favor you in any way. But, 0.3% of an eye does nothing, it doesn't give you any sense or help in survival or mating to pass down your genetic mutation. Or let's say we want a fish to come out of the water. Maybe a genetic mutation gave a fish 0.7% of a leg and 0.2% of a organ that allows the fish to function above water (a way to hunt, a way to breathe oxygen above water, etc.). Part of a leg or a little bit of a leg, or a way to hunt above water, or a way to breathe above water does not provide any favor over other fish because the fish isn't trying to survive above water, it is trying to survive below water.

I actually have a theory of an actual scientific explanation for consciousness. It starts with parmenides. You see, parmenides was basically the first determinist, he said that there was no real movement, that all that has happened and all that will happen exists as an unmoving whole, and that our perception of time and even the idea of the moment is just an illusion. And in fact, his theory is very close to the idea of Brane theory, and even though it doesn't get the WHOLE picture, it sets up an interesting paradox.
You see, in string theory, there are the 3 dimensions we are familiar with, as well as 3 extra dimensions of both hyperspace and subspace folded up in a tangled structure called the calabi-yao manifold, and also 2 more dimensions we only see a slice of: time, and supertime (aka parallel worlds). But if time itself is a dimension just like X, Y, and Z, doesn't that mean that what we consider to be motion along those dimensions, is actually just stillness in another dimension? How do we reconcile motion with the idea of determinism?
And yet, if we look further, we can see that the universe is NOT actually deterministic. We know that chaos theory makes it harder and harder to predict the motion of things over long periods of time due to convolution caused by micro changes within that system that have a ripple effect, which is why we can't predict the weather for more than a week in advance. We also know that at THE smallest level, the subatomic level, heisenbergs uncertainty principle applies, and we can't measure the speed of a particle and its position at the same time. And we also know that the phenomenon of consciousness, whatever it is, collapses the wave function and turns a superpostion of probability waves, into a singular reality due to creator / observer theory. And finally,


So, with this in mind, we can say that uncertainty, chaos, superposition and consciousness are all intertwined. We also know that entropy causes time to move forward rather than backwards, but we have no idea why consciousness as a phenomenon is entropic, being that it relates to the subatomic realm where such kinds of particles can even exist in multiple places or times. I would say that consciousness IS a form of extradimensional chaos. Imagine that our universe was a 2 dimensional and from that circle stemmed a large tree and every timeline of every one of an infinite number of realities that could exist became its own branch. One solid, unmoving tree. But consciousness... consciousness is the wind that blows the branches of that tree, so even an infinite number of fixed realities can vibrate across each other.

This video stretches the truth a bit. There's no evidence Western Scrub Jays are aware of other birds being like them.

Their "rationale" for relocating their stash is known as a "free floating rationale" and it is not proof of self-awareness or consciousness. It is a mental construct that has been built upon a series of increasingly complex survival mechanisms over millenia. "While hiding food, if a threat is detected, then don't hide food here."

But before that came threat detection and food preservation. The bird doesn't know why other birds are a threat, nor does it know why it hides its food. This is called "competence without comprehension".

I will say that it is an important concept in a conglomeration of processes by which consciousness might emerge in some form, but this just isn't evidence of consciousness.

These videos are good for generating curiosity but there are better ways to do that while also being viewer friendly.

Do stones never show behaviour?
I mean sure, conventionally speaking it may not carry a motion or a specific order. But when you get two rocks, non-conscious objects, hand it to a conscious organism with no eyes: first they’d might assume they’re holding a couple of rocks by texture, and hardness, because in relation to a living organism tissue the rock is quite hard. But say you take those rocks and you smash them together: if you are blind, you can’t see the sparks, if you’re deaf you won’t hear it’s sound, and if you had no tissue to hold with, you’d have no idea about the texture, now we’re getting a response, in that, if you go for a touch, you will observe the rock is hard but it’s not enough to convince you to know what the object is, you play with them hit one on another, now you’re getting sounds and small sparks that could potentially blaze up the whole place. So I guess what I’m trying to figure out here is if the rock, from a perspective of a blind and deaf person is such that: a rock is real therefore I feel and can throw it, but it’s not conscious or alive because it does not show ANY behavior. Yet here we are, able to see and hear that the rock responds to motion, right I mean, it cracks a sound, this may not be a very well observable form of conscience, but yet, certainly a very primitive form of it. My personal theory: Let's have a look at unconsciousness. Let's say when we sleep. We all know what it is like and we know that when you are in a deep sleep, a part of your brain turns off. So we know that consciousness is a process in the brain. Not just one process, but a lot of processes fed by our senses. Ears, eyes, skin etc.

When you die, you lose your body, because it stops working and it decays. You are forever unconscious.

How we can become conscious from dead chemistry however, I am still not sure.

What I am sure of however, is that your personality and mind is entirely dependent of your experience. Whatever information from the outside world your brain gets, will influence your mind.

That's as far as my theory goes anyway.

Consciousness has parts. If all these parts are not conscious, how is it that the whole is conscious? If all the parts of a bicycle is not green, the whole bicycle will never be green. In order for the whole to be conscious, at least one of the parts constituting consciousness has to be conscious. Therefore, panpsychism is right. Fundamental particles are conscious, as they constitute the whole of consciousness. Having said that, fundamental particles have low-level consciousness. Their consciousness isn’t as sophisticated as ours. Consciousness can come in degrees. Accordingly, it could be understood as a function of information-processing. The more information you process, the more conscious you are. Since fundamental particles do not process much information, their consciousness isn’t very high-level.

Awareness implies being able to observe. But being able to observe doesn't imply awareness. For example, when you dream, you might observe something scary and you will react to it without being aware it's not real. When you wake up, and awareness kicks in, you say, "How could I be so stupid and run away from a dragon? Obviously dragons aren't real!" Awareness is the ability to question even obvious things.Have you wondered how many fingers do you have on your left hand? When was the last time you counted them? Don't just look at them and say, "Five!" Count them! One by one. Only then you can say you have 5 fingers.

In fact, if you want to be able to have a lucid dream (a dream in which you know you're dreaming) – make a habit out of questioning obvious things. It may sound crazy or, make you look like a fool. But counting your fingers very carefully (one by one, slowly) or flipping a switch just to make sure the light turns on or off – such embarrassing reality checks, when they become a habit, they will kick in while you dream. And BOOM! You will flip a switch in your dream and the light won't switch off (or won't turn on). You will try to count your fingers and BOOM! you will find out it's... impossible. You will look at your watch, memorize the time, and then look again and see a completely random time.

For human babies it can be way earlier, the original object permanence task was designed by Piaget and deemed too complex as it involves both the ability to know that the object still exits, and the ability to retrieve the object by a complex sequence of event, thus it measured both decisions making and knowledge of physical properties of the object. A way easier task to assess object permanence is the one developed by Renée Baillargeon, named the visual habituation paradigm, and through visual habituation we can assess that children develop object permanence, or knowledge about physical properties of object by the age of 2-3 month

First, good job on a great video. I enjoyed hierarchical build-up of conciousness portrayed here. I do however have some things to point out.

I disagree with your statement that T. Adhaerens has no "need" for a conciousness. You even stated in the video that it slows down in proximity of nutrients, which by some definitions can be concidered a concious act. Therefore, excluding it as a possible first step of conciousness is inherently false.

Also, the definition of conciousness is a bit vague in the video, which might be natural for a topic of this complexity. A way it is possible to divide up conciousness is for instance: having an inner-experience or reacting on the environment. When conciousness is typically referred to it often implies both of the above (with self-conciousness as a subset where yourself is concidered a part of the environment). However, if they are analyzed seperately one can see that neither necessitates the other. The possibility of having an inner-experience might hint to an inherent property of the universe, giving pantheists a slight advocation. Reacting to the environment is simpler to understand; causality is in general intuitively understood. I could delve into some more philosophy here, but that would diverge too much from my intention.

I want to stress that the above is only one of many ways conciousness could be defined, and I put it forth to examplify the point that this video is a massive over-simplification. I would love a follow-up video where more definitions, or subsets thereof, are explored.

Understanding the idea of conciousness is really fucking easy, whats hard is knowing why it has to exist in the first place.
we are a system which takes in information and processes it in a way which allows us to survive, which is the purpose of the brain, that action of processing is dwelled on too much and made to seem alot more complex and "magical" than it really is because humans are intelligent, and intelligent ego absorbed people like to make things interesting instead of looking at objective reality.
We are intelligent because of an evolutionary attempt of "what if this works" and it happened to, just because we compute at a higher rate and with more complexity than an animal, it does not separate us or make us any less the same, and if you can understand that a dog has consciousness you can understand humans do too, and that it isnt done by magic just because its hard to grasp at first.
the brain makes decisions based on chemical balances and previously made pathways inside its self, which are formed via previous choices in the same way. which creates what we would recognise over time as a "personality", or a tendency to choose certain things.
As for knowing why it exists, my guess is that it randomly occurs in layers of oxygen like the one we live in, not all living things have to compute their surroundings to a level for which they need a whole organ to compute and store the information (eg: trees) so I would asssume that consciousness is just another evolutionary attempt to survive for longer, a method of processing our surroundings using the function of the brain.
Instead of looking at the question of the origin of consciousness (which only leads us to ask "why do brains form") we need to look into why organs form in the first place, why do things have a tendency (under the conditions we find ourselves in) to be alive?
I dont expect kurzgesagt to give such a straight forward answer as I did (even though he probably understands it in this way), because obviously you have to play into the "what if rocks are alive" stuff for a youtube audience to get "whoa" points and make people think at a more mystical and entertaining level, but I thought id have a go at answering anyway before I watched the entire video.

You started by acknowledging the debate on consciousness, but then equivocating everything under sun about cognition and calling it consciousness. Consciousness and awareness of the outside world are not the same thing. Take for instance, people with Blind Sight. They can react to the world as though they have sight, but do not have an inner representation of it. Nor would it even be the case, that all inner representations are in fact, conscious ones. We could very well have a computer do that. This is the problem with taking purely behaviorist approaches to consciousness, it tends to overexplain things beyond what is necessary. Of course, doing it minimally is unsatisfying, because it leaves us with more questions than answers, but that shouldn't deter us from doing due diligence.

It is a statement of belief and physicalist assumptions, which does not explain anything about consciousness since it is taken for granted.  How does the subjective, the qualia, arise from objective physical elements?  I hope that the other videos will show different points of view than physicalism.  The non-dualism of the Upanishads (Advaïta Védanta, Adi Shankara) or Erwin  Schrodinger for example.  The idea that consciousness is the basis from which Everything emerges, not the other way around, the phenomenological school, the arguments for and against physicalism, the hard problem of consciousness, etc... Here you talk about the complexity of the senses and the mind, never about consciousness.  Yes, an animal perceives more things than a bacterium, since it has eyes etc.  But consciousness is what makes there is perception. A fine video, breaking down consciousness into a series of evolutionarily advantageous and achievable steps, just like we can do with the development of complex systems like the eye. At what step did subjective experience become necessary — a required emergent property that came along for the ride with environmentally aware behavior?

The first time I came out of the fog as the consciousness I recognize as me, I was playing with colourful wooden blocks and I had felt the urge to poop, so I stood up from my blocks waddled out of my room and stared into the dark bathroom, looking at the toilet I knew I was supposed to use it but it was the first time I'd ever seen the bathroom dark so I continued to waddle down the hallway until I came to the living room where my mother was watching TV the far side of the room, and that's when I started to poop. I remember her asking me "Oh? are you pooping? do you need to poo?" and I faded back into the fog.

I consider this my earliest memory of the conscious being that I recognize is myself, and I believe it was making the connection that the sensation of going to the bathroom is connected to a series of outside actions(using the toilet) and that I shouldn't just "go" whenever I want.

If that's the case, if a body gets teleported as described, how does the metaphysical thing find the new body to connect to once the first one is destroyed? Or, if a malfunction happens and the new body is created without destroying the old one, and there is now a living copy of you somewhere else, does a new metaphysical thing come into existence to control it, or will it be mindless?
